description: These three photographs illustrate a base-measuring apparatus constructed in July, 1891, and employed by the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey Department in measuring the Holton (Indiana) Base in 1891, the Salina (Kansas) Base in 1896, and the Versailles (Missouri) Base in 1897 in connection with the Transcontiaental (Primary) Triangulation of the 39th Parallel of Latitude. The apparatus consists of two precisely similar base-bars, known as the U.S. C. & G. S. Nos. 13 and 14 measuring bars. Each bar is of the contact-slide metallic-thermometer type, and is 5 m. long at a certain temperature. The actual measuring unit is a steel rod 8 mm. in diam., terminating at one end in an agate plane, and at the other in a contact-slide which itself ends in an agate knife-edge. The slide is connected to the rod by a spring, and has a mark engraved upon it corresponding to a mark engraved upon the rod, so that when these two knife-edge and plane terminal points are the correct distance apart. Two zinc tubes, 9.5 mm. in diam., are soldered one to each end of the steel rod, their other ends being free to expand or contract relatively to this rod. The relative expansion is measured by means of a vernier on each zinc tube moving over a scale fixed to the steel rod, and the compound rod thus formed enables the mean temperature to be determined. The compound measuring rod rests upon rollers in a rectangular wooden case, which itself rests upon tripods during the measurement and is provided at its rear end with a telescope for aligning the bar. When the forward bar has been aligned and adjusted as a whole on its trestles to within a small distance of the preceding bar, its measuring rod is slowly drawn backwards upon the rollers by a milled screw at its rear end, until the contact-slide touches the agate plane of the preceding bar and is forced gently over the steel rod until the two engraved lines coincide. During this motion, the wooden case remains stationary upon its trestles, and the only pressure upon the rear bar is that due to the spring of the contact-slide, which is quite powerless to disturb the bar. Each bar is provided with a mercurial thermometer for use when comparing it with the standard bar. The average rate of measurement with this apparatus on the Holton Base was 155 m. per hr., with a probable error of about 1 in 1,500,000.

collection: PHOTOGRAPHS OF EIMBECK'S DUPLEX BASE APPARATUS
description: These three photographs illustrate a bimetallic contact-slide apparatus designed by W. Eimbeck, and used by the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey Department in measuring the Salt Lake Base (Utah) in 1896 in connection with the Transcontinental Triangulation of the 39th Parallel of Latitude. It consists of two similar bars, each 5 m. long, known as U. S. C. & G. S. Nos. 15 and 16 duplex bars. The rate of measuring with this apparatus in Utah was about 250 m. per hr., with a probable error of 1 in 5,000,000. Each bar consists of two measuring units of precisely similar construction, one of steel and one of brass, each 5 m. long, and weighs complete 118 lb. The measuring units are made of tubing of 3/4 in. diam., each having a thickness of wall corresponding to the conductivity and specific heat of the material of which it is made, so that under changing conditions each tube shall keep the same temperature as the other one. The two measuring tubes are carried on rollers in a brass protecting casing, which turns on its longitudinal axis in an outer brass protecting casing which remains stationary. The inner casing is rotated 180° from time to time to equalize temperature distribution. The two measuring units are entirely disconnected, and contact is always made brass to brass and steel to steel; hence two independent measurements of the base are obtained, their difference determining the average temperature during the measuring, so that each can be corrected accordingly. To overcome the difficulty due to one rod gradually gaining on the other, owing to the different coefficients of expansion of brass and steel, each measuring unit is provided with vernier scales, and the brass bar is occasionally readjusted by an amount thus measured and allowed for in the final calculations. Telescopes are affixed to each base-bar for aligning, whilst the tripods are provided with special heads for quick and slow adjustment in the horizontal and vertical planes. The contact slide is similar to the one described in connection with the Secondary Base-Apparatus.

description: These three photographs illustrate a form of tape-stretching apparatus which is an improvement upon the one used by the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey in measuring the Stanton Base, Texas, in 1908–09. It consists of an iron tube 1·35 m. long and 32 mm. diam., along which is movable a short collar fitted with a frame to carry the spring balance, and a weight to counterpoise it. The position of the sliding collar is easily adjusted by means of a friction lever device. The bottom of the tube ends in a round conical point, which permits it to rotate about its axis, thus allowing the tension to put the balance into alignment with the tape. A short iron projection near the bottom of the tube is used for forcing the latter into the ground by means of the foot. The total weight of the stretcher is 11 1/4 lb. The rear end of the tape is attached by a strap to a simple wooden staff fitted with a metal shoe, as shown in the left-hand photograph. The tension normally applied by this means to an "invar" tape for primary base-measure-ment is, in the United States, 15 kg. (See U.S. C. & G. S. Report, 1910, Appendix 4.)

description: The name "invar" has been given to a nickel-steel alloy containing from 35 per cent, to 36 per cent. nickel, discovered by Dr. C. E. Guillaume in 1896, owing to its low coefficient of expansion for temperature, which is not greater than 1·0 x 10⁻⁶ per °C. The application of this alloy to geodesy arises from the difficulty of ascertaining the exact mean temperature of a metal measuring unit, and consequently the precise length of the unit at the time of measurement. As the effect of an error of this type is directly proportional to the expansibility of the metal, the importance of a low coefficient of expansion is obvious. The use of "invar" wires or tapes, suspended under a constant tension of about 10 kg., according to Jäderin’s method, is now almost universal in measuring bases for triangulation of the first or second order. The tape exhibited is just over 100 ft. long, and has scales divided to read two-hundredths of a foot at each end. According to the National Physical Laboratory certificate of examination, the length between its zero marks at each end is 100·001 ft. at 58·5° F., under a tension of 10 kg., with an accuracy of 1 in 100,000. The width of the tape is 5 mm. and its thickness 0·5 mm. It is wound upon an aluminium drum of 16 in. diam., which can rotate upon its pivot as the reel is unwound.

collection: PHOTOGRAPHS OF BASE MEASUREMENT WITH "INVAR" WIRES.
object_name: Photographs of Base Measurement with "Invar" Wires
description: Four photographs of the measurement of the Narguta base in 1912, during the survey of Northern Nigeria, illustrate the general process of using flexible wires, suspended according to Jäderin’s method, and the superiority of such apparatus over rigid rods in difficult country. In this case a river, the Delimi, having fairly steep banks, was successfully negotiated without any special preparation of the ground. Two of the photographs illustrate the approach to the Delimi and its crossing, a third shows the crossing of a deep irrigation channel, and the fourth shows the completion of a section of the base, the terminal point being marked by a ground pin.
interpretation: Illustrate the general process of using flexible wires, suspended according to Jäderin’s method, and the superiority of such apparatus over rigid rods in difficult country. The Delimi river, having fairly steep banks, was successfully negotiated without any special preparation of the ground. Two of the photographs illustrate the approach to the Delimi and its crossing, a third shows the crossing of a deep irrigation channel, and the fourth shows the completion of a section of the base, the terminal point being marked by a ground pin.

description: This instrument was designed by Capt. G. H. Blakey, R.N. for determining the distance of a ship on the assumption that the height of its mast is known, and that the mast is perpendicular to the direction of the ship from the observer. It is merely a telescopic sighting tube having a pin-hole aperture and pairs of parallel wires set at known intervals apart near the object end of the tube. The distance of these wires from the aperture is given by the graduated scales on the telescopic tube. In using the instrument, the mast of the distant ship is viewed and the sighting tube telescoped until the mast lies exactly between a pair of wires. On reading the length of the tube, i.e. from aperture to wires, the range of the mast will be in the same ratio to this length as the mast is to the interval between the wires. As these last two lengths are known, the range is readily calculated, or can be obtained directly from the tables supplied with the instrument. Two mutually perpendicular pairs of parallel wires are fitted in the instrument exhibited, at intervals of one tenth and one twentieth of a foot respectively. A table corresponding to the former interval for lengths of masts between 100 and 200 ft., and all possible lengths of sighting tube is printed on the tube and gives the corresponding ranges in yards. For the smaller interval, these ranges are of course to be doubled. Measurements of distance by this apparatus can only be very approximate owing to the absence of magnification, uncertainty as regards the length of the mast and its inclination to the line of sight, etc.
measurements: ['100 and 200 ft.', 'one tenth', 'one twentieth of a foot']

description: Assuming that the length of a distant ship’s mast is known, its range can be found by this instrument, which was designed in 1895 for use at sea. Two images of the mast are seen in the field of the telescope, one formed by light rays traversing a fixed prism of constant angle, and the other by rays traversing a movable prism of varying angle. These images are made to approach each other until the lower limit of one is level with the upper limit of the other by sliding the movable prism, when the position of an index attached to this permits the range to be read. The movable prism consists of a thin piece of glass, ground concave on both faces, and is attached to a slide worked by a tangent screw. It thus forms a prism of varying angle in front of one half of the telescope, the other half being occupied by the fixed constant angle prism. Ranges up to 3 miles can be read to the nearest tenth of a mile.
interpretation: Designed for use at sea, this instrument finds the range of a distant ship by using two images of its mast, one formed by a fixed prism and the other by a movable prism. The movable prism's position, adjusted by a tangent screw, allows the range to be read.
interpretation_source: British Patent Specification, No. 23834

description: This is a pocket rangefinder suitable for military reconnaissance. To determine ranges up to 3,000 m. two observations are made with it, one from each end of a 30 m. base, which is set off approximately at right angles to the direction of the object. The instrument consists of a short metal tube having a pin-hole sight at one end and a rectangular window in one side. Opposite this window within the tube are two small plane mirrors inclined at an angle of 45° to each other. Both mirrors can be rotated slightly. The observer views the object A whose range is required directly through the pin-hole sight, and rotates one mirror until he sees, after double reflection, the image of an object B whose direction is nearly perpendicular to A's. He measures off the base in the direction of B, and again views A directly. By rotating the second mirror he once more gets a doubly reflected image of B. This latter rotation is effected by turning a milled drum in the eye end of the instrument, and the position of this drum when B is again sighted is a measure of the range of A. The drum is calibrated to give this range immediately. A thin cord of the base length is supplied with the instrument.
interpretation: This is a pocket rangefinder suitable for military reconnaissance.
interpretation_source: Fieldwork and Instruments

description: This instrument is used to measure ranges in the ordinary manner, by solving a very acute right-angled triangle. The angle subtended at the distant point is constant, whilst the base is variable, and is measured by pacing. Three reflecting right-angled prisms are mounted by hinged joints near the objective of a small telescope, so that any one of the three can be set to reflect rays axially along the telescope from directions at 90°, 88° 51′ 15″ and 74° 53′ 15″ respectively. The first prism is used to set off the base at right angles to the direction of the distant object. The observer paces in the line of the base until, using one of the other two prisms, he again sees the object by reflection. For both observations the telescope is directed to view another distant point at right angles to the target, i.e., in the direction of the base. The number of paces taken between the two observations, multiplied by a constant depending upon the length of pace and the reflecting angle of the second prism used, gives the required range. The constant is determined experimentally.
interpretation: This instrument is used to measure ranges in the ordinary manner, by solving a very acute right-angled triangle. The angle subtended at the distant point is constant, whilst the base is variable, and is measured by pacing. The first prism is used to set off the base at right angles to the direction of the distant object. The observer paces in the line of the base until, using one of the other two prisms, he again sees the object by reflection. For both observations the telescope is directed to view another distant point at right angles to the target, i.e., in the direction of the base. The number of paces taken between the two observations, multiplied by a constant depending upon the length of pace and the reflecting angle of the second prism used, gives the required range. The constant is determined experimentally.

description: This rangefinder was designed by Capt. Gautier, a French artillery officer, about 1865, and has been extensively used in the French army. Its main feature is a thin prism mounted in a ring at the object end of the sighting tube. By rotating the ring the deviation of rays in the plane of the distant object and the horizontal through the instrument can be varied continuously, and the ring calibrated correspondingly. The sighting tube is about 5 in. long by 1·5 in. diam. and has a protecting tube which can be fitted underneath to serve as a hand-grip when observations are being made. The sighting tube, in addition to the movable ring containing the prism, has a pair of plane mirrors having their faces inclined to each other at an angle of about 45°, and so inclined to the optical axis that rays incident through a window in the side of the tube in a direction nearly perpendicular to the axis, are doubly reflected at the mirrors into the line of the axis, and pass through a small telescope at the eye end of the tube. In the instrument shown, two such telescopes of different powers are fixed side by side. One of the mirrors can be slightly rotated so as to vary the angle of deviation of the reflected rays. In using the instrument, the observer sets the range scale on the movable ring at “infinity” and the index of the movable mirror at the centre. He views the distant object by double reflection at the mirrors and looks directly through the tube and prism for a convenient aiming mark. If such a mark is not quite co-incident with the image of the distant object, he rotates the mirror until coincidence occurs. Then the object and the aiming mark are in directions nearly perpendicular to each other. Next he paces out a convenient distance in the direction of the aiming mark and takes a second observation similar to the first, but this time effects the coincidence by means of the movable prism. He reads off the scale calibrated on that ring when coincidence is effected and multiplies the distance of his base. The result is the range of the distant object. The movable ring is really calibrated to record the reciprocal of the angle of deviation caused by the prism, which is the same as the reciprocal of the angle subtended. by the base at the object. As this base has been made nearly perpendicular to the direction of the object, the product of its length and the reciprocal of the angle gives the range. Thus any convenient base length can be used subject to the condition that it subtends an angle of not more than 3° at the distant object. (See “ Notice sur le Télémètre de Poche,” by A. Gautier, Paris.) Inv.

description: This standard rangefinding set is used by infantry units. It comprises two optical sighting instruments, known as the “Right Angle” and “Reading” instruments, and two reels of cord, each 25 yd. long, for setting off the base. The observer at one end of the base uses the “Right Angle” instrument to make the base line perpendicular to the line joining his position to the distant object, after which the other observer uses his “Reading” instrument to measure the angle between the base line and the direction of the object from his position. The Right Angle instrument has two fixed vertical mirrors inclined to each other at an angle of 45°. The observer using this sees the target directly and the vane on the Reading instrument after double reflection at the two mirrors. He adjusts his position, keeping the base line fully extended, until the two images coincide. The Reading instrument differs only in that one of its mirrors can be rotated, and the rotation recorded upon a graduated drum, so that the images of the target (viewed directly) and the vane of the Right Angle instrument (viewed by double reflection on the two mirrors) can be made to coincide. The graduated drum is calibrated to record the range directly.
interpretation: This standard rangefinding set is used by infantry units.
interpretation_source: Handbook of the Mekometer

description: The rangefinder consists of two systems of lenses and right-angled reflecting prisms mounted in a 3-ft. metal tube of square section. Each system forms a “broken” telescope, the objectives being at each end of the tube, along which the rays, originally perpendicular to it, are deflected by right-angled prisms to the centre, where they are again reflected at right angles into the common central eye-piece. In this manner two images of a distant object whose direction is nearly perpendicular to the axis of the tube are obtained, one through each system. These images will be separated laterally by an interval which diminishes continuously as the range increases, but does not become zero until the object is at an infinite distance. If the objective lens and two prisms of one system are separately mounted and can be rotated with respect to the other system, the two images may be made to coincide by such a rotation, and the angle of rotation necessary will vary inversely as the range of the object. This angle can be obtained by calculation, or a table of corresponding values. In the instrument exhibited such an arrangement is effected by mounting one object lens and its pair of reflecting prisms in a separate tube within the main tube containing the other set, and pivoted to this so that the rotation can be effected by a screw threaded in the outer tube with its end pressing against the inner. The angle of rotation is measured by a vernier on one tube and a scale nearest second of arc, and the range read off on a table fixed to the outer leather protecting cover.
interpretation: This type of rangefinder was designed by P. Adie in 1860, and was extensively used by the Admiralty until superseded by the Barr and Stroud pattern. The example shown was used on H.M.S. “Triton” from 1885 to 1904 during the survey of the East Coast of England.
interpretation_source: ['British Patent, 1860, No. 357', 'British Patent, 1863, No. 608']

description: This instrument was made in 1889, and is one of the first rangefinders constructed by Messrs. Barr & Stroud for use by infantry. It is a single-observation, coincidence instrument, with a fixed base of 80 cm., and measures ranges between 200 and 2,000 yd. with a percentage error directly proportional to the distance. The instrument is optically equivalent to a pair of telescopes having a common central eye-piece and their axes in opposite directions along the base-line, at the ends of which are the two objective lenses. Two pencils of rays diverging from the distant object to each end of the instrument are reflected at right angles by mirrors so as to traverse the objectives and form two images at the centre, where they are again reflected at right angles by a pair of mirrors, one of which is parallel to each end mirror. The two images are thus viewed in the focal plane of the right eyepiece of the instrument, and are separated laterally by a distance inversely proportional to the required range. Between the right objective lens and the central mirrors there is a small angled deflecting prism, which can move along the axis, and in so doing increases or decreases the amount of separation of the two images. In one position of the prism, corresponding to the distance of the object, the two images coincide. A scale attached to the prism moves with it and is graduated so as to give the range directly. This scale and its fixed index-line are viewed by the observer’s left eye in a separate eyepiece, which also serves in conjunction with a field lens as a small telescope of large field for picking up the target.
measurements: ['base of 80 cm.', 'measures ranges between 200 and 2,000 yd.']
interpretation: This instrument was made in 1889, and is one of the first rangefinders constructed by Messrs. Barr & Stroud for use by infantry. It is a single-observation, coincidence instrument. The two images are thus viewed in the focal plane of the right eyepiece of the instrument, and are separated laterally by a distance inversely proportional to the required range. Between the right objective lens and the central mirrors there is a small angled deflecting prism, which can move along the axis, and in so doing increases or decreases the amount of separation of the two images. In one position of the prism, corresponding to the distance of the object, the two images coincide. A scale attached to the prism moves with it and is graduated so as to give the range directly. This scale and its fixed index-line are viewed by the observer’s left eye in a separate eyepiece, which also serves in conjunction with a field lens as a small telescope of large field for picking up the target.

collection: BARR AND STROUD RANGEFINDER ON NAVAL MOUNTING
description: This instrument was used by Dr. Bruce in the Weddell Sea Antarctic expedition on the “Scotia,” 1902–04, and afterwards by Capt. R. F. Scott, R.N., on the “Terra Nova” in the British Antarctic expedition 1910–13.
makers_and_associated_people: [{'name': 'Barr & Stroud, Ltd', 'role': 'lender'}, {'name': 'Dr. Bruce', 'role': 'user'}, {'name': 'Capt. R. F. Scott, R.N.', 'role': 'user'}]
interpretation: This instrument was used by Dr. Bruce in the Weddell Sea Antarctic expedition on the “Scotia,” 1902–04, and afterwards by Capt. R. F. Scott, R.N., on the “Terra Nova” in the British Antarctic expedition 1910–13.

description: Designed by Prof. Forbes in 1901, for use by infantry in measuring ranges up to 3,000 yd. The power of the eyes to “converge” to a varying degree upon objects at different distances, and to measure distances by the muscular effort so required, is limited normally to small distances of a few yards. Consequently, in this, as in all stereoscopic rangefinders, optical means are employed to bring the image of the object ranged upon within the limit of normal eye convergence. The use of an optical base, whose function is to increase the inter-ocular distance from 2·5 in. to 72 in., and a pair of binoculars of magnification 8 diam. enables the radius of stereoscopic vision to be increased 240 times. balloon. The distance between the two balloon images is varied by a micrometer screw. If the observer combines these balloon images stereoscopically into one, and does the same with the images of the distant object, he can judge the apparent distances of the two images, and turn the screw until these distances coincide. The rotation of the screw thus serves as a measure of the required range, and this can be read off directly on a circular scale, attached to the screw and suitably graduated.
measurements: up to 3,000 yd; 2·5 in.; 72 in.; 8 diam.
interpretation: Designed for use by infantry in measuring ranges. The principle of operation relies on optical means to bring the image of the object ranged upon within the limit of normal eye convergence, by increasing the inter-ocular distance and using binoculars of magnification. The observer judges apparent distances of combined stereoscopic images to determine the required range, which is read on a graduated circular scale.

description: A Porro "anallatic" lens is inserted between the objective and eye lenses of this instrument and its horizontal and vertical circles are divided centesimally. It is used in conjunction with a graduated tacheometric staff, upon which the interval subtended between the fixed cross wire varies directly as the distance of the staff from the transverse axis of the instrument, which is itself vertically above the observing station point.
interpretation: A Porro "anallatic" lens is inserted between the objective and eye lenses of this instrument and its horizontal and vertical circles are divided centesimally. It is used in conjunction with a graduated tacheometric staff, upon which the interval subtended between the fixed cross wire varies directly as the distance of the staff from the transverse axis of the instrument, which is itself vertically above the observing station point.

description: Made by Stärke & Kammerer, Vienna. To convert a theodolite into a tacheometer for measuring distances, many devices have been proposed which permit the telescope, when directed upon a graduated staff, to be displaced through a constant small angle, whose limits are determined by two mechanical stops. The distance so measured on the staff will vary directly as the horizontal distance of the staff from the observing station and inversely as the square of the cosine of the altitude angle. As the latter is known, the former can be calculated by using special tables. In the tacheometer invented about 1868 by A. Gentilli, the Austrian engineer, a rigid vertical arm can be clamped to the transverse axis of the telescope in any position. The lower end of this arm can only move a short distance, being limited by two mechanical stops. Consequently the vertical angle through which the telescope can move when clamped to the arm is likewise limited. The instrument in other respects is like an ordinary theodolite of the type made by Stärke about this period. It has a 5-in. horizontal circle and a 3.5-in. vertical quadrant, both reading by vernier and reading microscope to 30'' and having the usual clamps and tangent screws. The telescope has an objective lens of 12 in. focal length and 1.5 in. aperture. The instrument has four levelling screws, two small spirit levels mutually perpendicular on the horizontal circle, and a more sensitive one on the telescope.
measurements: ['5-in. horizontal circle', '3.5-in. vertical quadrant', "30''", '12 in. focal length', '1.5 in. aperture']
interpretation: To convert a theodolite into a tacheometer for measuring distances, many devices have been proposed which permit the telescope, when directed upon a graduated staff, to be displaced through a constant small angle, whose limits are determined by two mechanical stops. The distance so measured on the staff will vary directly as the horizontal distance of the staff from the observing station and inversely as the square of the cosine of the altitude angle. As the latter is known, the former can be calculated by using special tables.

description: An early example of a theodolite modified to enable distances to be measured with it simultaneously with azimuth and altitude angles is here represented in the “Omnimeter,” invented by C. A. C. Eckhold in 1868. This instrument is used in conjunction with a special tacheometric staff having a fixed interval, usually 10 ft., marked upon it. A microscope, rigidly attached with its axis perpendicular to that of the observing telescope, rotating with this telescope about a common transverse axis, measures upon a scale fixed horizontally upon the upper plate of the theodolite the distance traversed when the observing telescope is rotated from the upper mark to the lower mark of the staff. As this staff is always set up vertically, its horizontal distance from the centre of the instrument is inversely proportional to the distance traversed on the scale. The microscope scale is mounted parallel to the telescope at a distance of exactly 6 in. below the transverse axis. It is 4 in. long and is graduated to read 0·02 in. directly, whilst it can be moved on the plate, parallel to its own length, through a small interval by means of a micrometer screw with a graduated drum, which measures 0·002 of each division of the scale. In this manner the ultimate graduation of the scale corresponds to 4 × 10⁻⁵ in. so that, if n such divisions are traversed when the theodolite rotates from the upper to the lower mark of the staff, the distance of this staff from the instrument will be 15 × 10³ ÷ n ft. In other respects the instrument is similar to an ordinary transit repeating theodolite. It has 5-in. vertical and horizontal circles reading by vernier to single minutes. The focal length of the telescope is 11 in., and its aperture 1·25 in. It is fitted with a Ramsden eyepiece. Slow-motion tangent screws are provided for each circle, and the usual spirit-levels on the plate and telescope. A diagonal eyepiece is fitted to the microscope for convenience in taking steep sights.
interpretation: An early example of a theodolite modified to enable distances to be measured with it simultaneously with azimuth and altitude angles.

description: Ordinary tacheometers are designed for horizontal sights, and the readings have to be corrected by computation if the sight is inclined, whilst a further calculation is necessary to determine the difference in height between the observed and observing stations. Many devices have been introduced in the design of tacheometers with the object of rendering such calculations unnecessary, and enabling the distance and altitude to be read off directly, whether the line of sight is horizontal or inclined. The tacheometer illustrated embodies Prof. H. H. Jeffcott’s arrangement for rendering the readings independent of the inclination. A similar arrangement of varying diaphragm-interval enables the height also to be obtained by reading the staff-interval intercepted. The diaphragm has one fixed and two movable horizontal platinum-iridium pointers, the former for collimation and the latter to limit the intervals for height and distance readings respectively: the distance pointer is on the same side as the collimation pointer, and the height pointer on the opposite side. Each movable pointer is fixed on the end of a pivoted lever, of which the other end is pressed against a suitably shaped cam, which is rotated by the movement in inclination of the telescope, so that the distance of either movable pointer from the fixed one is suitably varied to make the interval intercepted upon the distant staff exactly one-hundredth of the range and one-tenth of the height respectively. The cams are made to suit elevations and depressions up to 30°, and are mounted inside a protecting case at one end of the transit axis of the telescope. The instrument in other respects resembles the ordinary tacheometric theodolite. It has a 5-in. horizontal circle, graduated on silver to 20 minutes and read by two verniers; one coarse vernier for ordinary use reads to 1 minute whilst the other, reading to 20 seconds, is only used in adjusting or testing the instrument. No vertical circle is supplied, unless specially desired. The telescope is provided with an anallatic lens, an objective of 1.65 in. aperture, and a screw-focussing, inverting eyepiece of power 18. The eyepiece is mounted in a movable slide for reading at extreme angles. Three bubble-levels are provided, one on the cover-plate, another above the telescope, and the third on the control arm of the cams; this last is particularly sensitive, having a bubble shift of 2 mm. per 15-20 seconds of elevation.

description: This is a 4-metre wooden staff, graduated in centimetres and used in conjunction with the tacheometer, Cat. No. 81. It is inextensible, and does not materially differ from a levelling rod. The graduation marks are black bands, 1 cm. wide, at intervals of 1 cm. Those corresponding to metres and decimetres extend right across the face, the rest only half across. The metres are numbered by large red numbers and the decimetres by smaller black numbers. The half-decimetre points are marked by small black arrows. The rod has a rectangular section, 3 in. wide by 1 1/4 in. deep, and the face is slightly sunk below the edges to prevent abrasion of the graduations.
materials: wood; black bands; red numbers; black numbers
measurements: 4-metre; 1 cm. wide; 1 cm. intervals; 3 in. wide; 1 1/4 in. deep
interpretation: Used in conjunction with the tacheometer. Does not materially differ from a levelling rod. The face is slightly sunk below the edges to prevent abrasion of the graduations.

object_name: PHOTOGRAPH OF TWO ANCIENT EGYPTIAN LEVELS
description: The original levels, which are of the A-shaped plummet type, are exhibited in the Cairo Museum and are of considerable antiquity. Such levels were used by builders and engineers of all the early civilizations and have survived in use to the present date without fundamental modification. Each level consists of a wooden frame in the shape of an isosceles triangle, having its sides equally prolonged beyond the base. The ends of the legs are cut parallel to the cross piece, so that the frame may rest upon a flat surface. A plummet is suspended from the apex of the frame, and its cord passes over the front of the cross piece, in the middle of which is engraved a vertical mark. If the cord lies along this mark when the plummet hangs freely, the surface on which the level rests is horizontal. Hieroglyphics are engraved in the face of the lower level.
interpretation: Such levels were used by builders and engineers of all the early civilizations and have survived in use to the present date without fundamental modification. If the cord lies along this mark when the plummet hangs freely, the surface on which the level rests is horizontal.

description: This consists of an isosceles, right-angled metal triangle which can be freely suspended by means of two brass pins so that its two equal sides are vertical and horizontal respectively. All objects in the prolongation of its third side will then be at a horizontal distance from the instrument equal to their height above it. The former distance can be measured, and the height thus ascertained. The hypotenuse of the metal triangle has a pair of sights which enable objects in its line to be viewed. When using the instrument, the observer takes up a position from which he can sight the object whose height is required, the instrument being freely suspended. He then measures his horizontal distance from a point vertically beneath the object. This distance is equal to the height of the object above the eye-level of the observer. When not in use, the instrument fits in the wooden case exhibited with it.
interpretation: This instrument is used for ascertaining heights. It works by suspending a right-angled metal triangle. Objects in the prolongation of its third side are at a horizontal distance from the instrument equal to their height above it. This distance can be measured to ascertain the height. The hypotenuse has sights for viewing objects. The observer sights the object, measures the horizontal distance from a point vertically beneath the object, which equals the height above the observer's eye-level. The instrument fits in a wooden case.

description: This is a level of a type much used for rough levelling during the 17th century, and probably dates from the latter half of that period. It consists of a heavy tube freely suspended from the top of a wooden case by a thread attached to its centre. The tube has a horizontal slit at one end, and a corresponding cross wire at the other; glass windows in the ends of the wooden case permit a free view along the sights. The instrument as a whole can be rotated in azimuth upon its stand. When not in use, the sighting tube can be fixed by means of two screws passing through the bottom of the wooden case. In this instrument, the centre of gravity of the suspended tube is very little, if any, below the line of sight. Hence the tube is very sensitive to disturbances, which is a source of trouble. Moreover, there is no easy method of adjusting the line of sight to be truly horizontal. Owing to these defects, both of which were remedied in the more precise instruments on the "balance" principle designed by Huygens, this type of level is not very accurate. The body of the tube is made of lead, the ends containing the sights being of brass. The wooden case is screwed into the top of a small column, provided with a brass socket at its other end. The socket serves to attach the level to its stand, which may be a tripod or simply a "stick" stand.
interpretation: ['This is a level of a type much used for rough levelling during the 17th century, and probably dates from the latter half of that period.', 'The instrument as a whole can be rotated in azimuth upon its stand.', 'When not in use, the sighting tube can be fixed by means of two screws passing through the bottom of the wooden case.', 'In this instrument, the centre of gravity of the suspended tube is very little, if any, below the line of sight.', 'Hence the tube is very sensitive to disturbances, which is a source of trouble.', 'Moreover, there is no easy method of adjusting the line of sight to be truly horizontal.', 'Owing to these defects, both of which were remedied in the more precise instruments on the "balance" principle designed by Huygens, this type of level is not very accurate.', 'The socket serves to attach the level to its stand, which may be a tripod or simply a "stick" stand.']
interpretation_source: ['Plate II, Fig. 1, p. 38.']

description: late 17th or early 18th century This instrument was made in the late 17th or early 18th century, and consists of a brass alidade attached to a semi-circle, pivoted upon a heavy stand, which is set with its base horizontal by means of a small brass plummet. The semi-circle and alidade can be rotated in the vertical plane, and the inclination of the line of sight read by a fixed index on the stand. The semi-circle is graduated in degrees and has a diameter of 4·2 in. The sight rule is a hollow tube fitted with dual sights at each end, one set being within the tube and the other on top of it in the opposite sense.
interpretation: This instrument was madewhich is set with its base horizontal by means of a small brass plummet. The semi-circle and alidade can be rotated in the vertical plane, and the inclination of the line of sight read by a fixed index on the stand.

description: This is a German instrument made in 1755, and consists of a hollow wooden stand with a flat base and brass facings. A brass plummet is suspended down one face, and by its position on a scale of degrees engraved on the lower part of the face measures the inclination of the base of the instrument. No sights are provided. A brass knob, screwed into the top of the stand can be detached and used as a plummet; a cord wound round a drum inside the stand is used to suspend the knob. The plummet has a length of 4·8 in., which is the radius of the graduated arc. This extends 15° on either side of the vertical.
interpretation: measures the inclination of the base of the instrument.

description: This instrument can be used for testing whether a surface is horizontal, vertical or inclined at 45°. It consists of a loaded disc, pivoted between the vertical faces of a cylindrical brass case fixed to a brass ruler. Marks engraved on the edge of the revolving disc show by their coincidence with marks on the fixed case whether the ruler, which is placed on the surface to be tested, is horizontal, vertical, or inclined at 45°.
interpretation: This instrument can be used for testing whether a surface is horizontal, vertical or inclined at 45°.

description: This type of level was invented by Col. Burel in 1829, and operates upon the principle that in a vertically suspended mirror the eye sees a reflected image of itself at its own level. The instrument consists of a rectangular frame, suspended in gimbal bearings so as to hang vertical owing to its own weight. The frame contains a piece of plane glass, of which one vertical half is silvered and the other half left free for direct vision of a distant object. A horizontal cross wire bisects the two parts. The observer holds the instrument in front of his eye and moves it until he sees the reflected image of his eye bisected by the cross wire. Any distant object then intersected by the wire will be at the level of his eye.
interpretation: This type of level operates upon the principle that in a vertically suspended mirror the eye sees a reflected image of itself at its own level. The observer holds the instrument in front of his eye and moves it until he sees the reflected image of his eye bisected by the cross wire. Any distant object then intersected by the wire will be at the level of his eye.
interpretation_source: Memorial de l'Officier du Génie

description: This is very similar to the adjacent Burel type, but has a heavy screw threaded in the base of the frame. By working the screw the inclination of the plane of the mirror can be varied, and adjusted to be truly vertical by means of a test sight. The mirror also occupies much more than half of the frame, leaving a small part only for direct vision.
interpretation: By working the screw the inclination of the plane of the mirror can be varied, and adjusted to be truly vertical by means of a test sight. The mirror also occupies much more than half of the frame, leaving a small part only for direct vision.

description: Of the many arrangements for converting a Burel reflecting level into a clinometer, the one here represented, devised by General A. De Lisle, R.E., is the most satisfactory. A heavy arc is attached to the lower part of the mirror frame and can be turned into the same plane as the mirror for convenience of carriage, or into a perpendicular frame for measuring angles of elevation or depression. In the latter position the weight of the arc causes the mirror plane to take up an inclination to the vertical, which can be varied by means of a movable radial arm, concentric with the arc and carrying a sliding counterpoise at its extremity. The arc is so graduated on its edge that the position of one edge of the movable arm gives the inclination of the mirror, and, therefore, of the line of sight between the observer's eye and its reflection in the mirror. The arc is graduated to read gradients from zero to 1 in 5.

description: Constructed in the early part of the 19th century (Used in 1831) This level was constructed in the early part of the 19th century and used in 1831 by J. A. Lloyd, F.R.S., in ascertaining the differences of level between the Thames at London Bridge, Sheerness and various intermediate points. The telescope has a focal length of 28 in. and is finally levelled by means of a 12-in. spirit level mounted at one side parallel to its axis. The objective lens of the telescope has a 2-in. aperture, and is fixed in the tube, the eyepiece tube being focussed by a rack and pinion arrangement and having a fixed diaphragm and a slide focussing Ramsden inverting eyepiece. The telescope is attached to a transverse horizontal axis, which rests in Y-s on standards fixed to the horizontal plate. The telescope is supported near both ends by vertical screws threaded in the ends of a rigid bar fixed to the horizontal plate parallel to the axis of the telescope. These screws are used in the final adjustment of the telescope axis, which is tested by the main spirit level. This bar is suspended from the ends of a metal rod fixed on one side of the telescope, and has ivory scales graduated to thirtieths of an inch mounted above its bubble-tube. A small level is also fixed transversely at one end of the main level. The bubble of the latter moves over one division of the scale when the telescope is elevated about 2 seconds of arc. The horizontal plate can rotate about a vertical axis, and has a clamp and tangent screw for slow motion. It is attached to a pair of parallel plates, connected by four levelling screws of the usual type. A small circular spirit-level is fixed to the plate above its centre for setting it horizontal. The telescope can be reversed in its Y-s end for end, or rotated through 180° about its own axis, as in all Y-levels.
interpretation: in ascertaining the differences of level between the Thames at London Bridge, Sheerness and various intermediate points.
interpretation_source: Phil. Trans. Roy. Soc., 1831

description: Plate II, Fig. 2, p. 38. Made by Cary. Lent by the Royal Society. Made about the year 1830 and was used in 1831 This level was made about the year 1830 and was used in 1831 by J. A. Lloyd, F.R.S., in measuring the differences of level between the Thames at London Bridge, Sheerness and various intermediate points. It has a 30-in. telescope mounted in Y-s in a manner similar to the ordinary Y-level, but is fitted with an extra spirit level suspended above the telescope, and also has a circular supporting base resembling that of a large theodolite and resting on three footscrews. The objective lens of the telescope has a 2-in. aperture and is fixed in the tube, the eyepiece tube having a rack and pinion focussing movement. The eyepiece is of the Ramsden inverting type and is also focussed by a rack and pinion movement. Gun-metal collars are shrunk on to the telescope near its extremities and rest in Y-s fixed to the horizontal circle. One of these Y-s can be adjusted vertically by means of a screw. This adjustment serves to level the telescope more precisely than is possible with the footscrews. The 14-in. horizontal circle can rotate about a vertical axis, and has a clamp and tangent screw. It also carries a central 31-in. compass, graduated in degrees, and a small thermometer. The supporting base of the instrument consists of two horizontal circles of 14 in. diameter connected by three vertical pillars to which the three foot-screws are fixed. Beneath the telescope a 17-in. spirit level is mounted in adjustable bearings, and a 22-in. level of similar construction can be suspended above the telescope from pivots carried by brackets fixed to the end of the tube. Both pivots are adjustable. Each level has ivory scales, graduated to twentieths of an inch mounted above its tube. Small transverse levels are also fixed to the telescope and at one end of the suspended level. (See Phil. Trans. Roy. Soc., 1831.) Inv. 1900-154. S.M. 1938.
interpretation: ['measuring the differences of level between the Thames at London Bridge, Sheerness and various intermediate points.', 'This adjustment serves to level the telescope more precisely than is possible with the footscrews.']
interpretation_source: ['Phil. Trans. Roy. Soc., 1831']

description: This level was formerly the property of George Stephenson, and was used by him at Chat Moss in the survey for the Manchester and Liverpool Railway, 1829. It is of the type designed and constructed by Troughton, the spirit-level being rigidly fixed in the telescope, which is not reversible, as in the Ramsden type. Such an instrument, whilst incapable of preliminary adjustment, is very simple and rigid in construction, and is well suited for engineering surveys. A small compass, supported on four pillars, is provided for traversing. The telescope has an aperture of 1 1/4 in. and a focal length of 15 in., and is provided with stops. The eyepiece tube is focussed by a rack and pinion arrangement actuated by a screw. The diaphragm can easily be disclosed for examination by removing the eyepiece. There are two eyepieces provided, one erect and the other inverting. The bubble-tube is 10 in. long, and has a radius of curvature of about 50 ft., giving a motion of the bubble of 1/5 in. for every minute of arc. The compass ring is 2 1/2 in. in diameter, and is graduated to read single degrees.
interpretation: Such an instrument, whilst incapable of preliminary adjustment, is very simple and rigid in construction, and is well suited for engineering surveys.

description: This instrument was made about the middle of the 19th century, and was used until 1907 for levelling minor lines. The spirit level is attached by adjusting screws to the telescope, which fits in Y-shaped bearings, and can be rotated or reversed in these for adjustment of the line of collimation. The parallel plate arrangement for levelling the instrument is of the usual type, with four levelling-screws, axis clamp and tangent-screw for slow-motion. The telescope has a focal length of 12 in. and an aperture of 1.25 in., and is provided with stops. The focussing is carried out at the objective end by means of a rack and pinion arrangement, actuated by an external screw. The diaphragm containing a horizontal and vertical wire is easily accessible after unscrewing the eyepiece, which is arranged to give an erect image of the staff. The bubble-tube is 7 3/4 in. long, and is graduated in tenths of an inch. The internal radius of curvature of the tube is about 80 ft., giving a movement of the bubble of 0.1 in., corresponding to a change of elevation of 20 seconds. Inv.

description: This level was made between 1840 and 1850 and was used for levelling of second-order lines. The spirit level is graduated to read 5 seconds of elevation, and is attached to the telescope, which rests in Y-shaped bearings, and can be rotated or reversed for adjustment of the line of collimation. A compass is provided for rough traversing, and an elevating screw permits the telescope to be finally levelled with great accuracy. In the diaphragm are two vertical and one horizontal wires. The telescope has a focal length of 18 in. and an erecting eyepiece. The aperture is 1.5 in. The eyepiece is adjusted for parallax by a sliding tube arrangement, whilst the telescope is focussed on the staff by a rack and pinion which moves the objective. The compass-ring has a diameter of 3 1/4 in. and is graduated to read single degrees. The spirit level tube is 10 in. long, and is graduated at intervals of 1/4 in., each interval corresponding to 5 seconds of arc. The parallel plate arrangement is of the usual type, and a slow-motion tangent screw is provided for azimuth setting.
interpretation: was used for levelling of second-order lines.

description: This level was made in 1841 and was used in first-order levelling for the Ordnance Survey. It has a telescope of 2·2-in. aperture and 23-in. focal length, with a 12-in. spirit level attached, reading to single seconds of arc. The telescope rests in Y bearings, in which it can be rotated and also reversed end for end, for adjustments. A small transverse level is also provided on the telescope for rough levelling, whilst the final accurate setting is performed by means of an elevating screw, which moves one bearing. The instrument has a 5⅛-in. compass fitted to its alidade for rough traversing, the compass being graduated in single degrees. There is also the usual parallel-plate levelling arrangement, with four screws, for setting the alidade approxi- mately horizontal. A slow motion tangent screw is provided for setting the instru- ment accurately in azimuth. The telescope has a micrometer eyepiece, and is focussed on the staff by moving the eyepiece tube. The spirit level has an ivory scale above each end, graduated in 1/20 in., each division corresponding to about 2 seconds of arc of elevation.

description: A level of this type, serving also for measuring inclines and distances by means of the elevating screw, is particularly adapted by reason of its compactness and simplicity of construction for preliminary surveys where no great accuracy is required. It consists of a small telescope and spirit-level separately mounted upon a platform connected with a tripod by means of a ball-and-socket joint of a special type, often employed in small surveying instruments of German construction. This joint permits the orientation of the platform to be varied, whilst leaving it perfectly free to rotate in azimuth about the socket, which is fixed to the tripod. The platform terminates underneath in a metal ball, at the lower end of which is a cylindrical pin. The socket consists of two parts screwed together, an upper spherical dome enclosing the ball, and a lower tubular sheath surrounding the pin. Two levelling screws, set perpendicularly to each other, work in threads in this sheath, and impinge upon a metal collar which encircles the pin sufficiently tightly to prevent shake, but not to hinder the free azimuthal rotation of the pin, and consequently the platform. Opposite the two screws, and likewise impinging on the collar is a spring which takes the pressure of the screws. By means of these screws the platform can be set level in all directions. The spirit level can be adjusted upon the platform by the small screws at one end of its case, whilst the telescope can be elevated or depressed about an axis at one end fixed in the platform by means of a fine-threaded screw at the other end. The pitch of the screw-threads is half a millimetre, and the movement of this end of the telescope is read to a tenth of a millimetre with the aid of a graduated disc and vertical millimetre scale. For every tenth-millimetre, the line of sight of the telescope moves through an angle whose circular measure is one-thousandth. By this means, as in tacheometry, distances can be measured with fair accuracy.

interpretation: A level of this type, serving also for measuring inclines and distances by means of the elevating screw, is particularly adapted by reason of its compactness and simplicity of construction for preliminary surveys where no great accuracy is required. description: This instrument, primarily designed for levelling, can also be employed for measuring angles in any plane, and is likewise provided with stadia lines in the diaphragm of the telescope for measuring distances. It is thus a type of cheap, portable, universal instrument, specially adapted for surveys of minor precision. The special features which distinguish it from an ordinary small level are the graduated semicircle and the peculiar method of attaching the spirit level to the telescope and the whole instrument to the tripod. The lower parallel plate is not attached directly to the tripod head, but to an intermediate knuckle-joint piece, which permits the instrument as a whole to be set with the semicircle in any plane. The spirit level can also be attached to the telescope in two places, one serving when the semicircle is horizontal and the other when it is vertical. The telescope can rotate on the semicircle, which is graduated to 30 minutes and reads by vernier to 2 minutes, and the semicircle can likewise rotate irrespective of the telescope, thus permitting angles to be “repeated.” The diameter of the graduated semicircle is 18 cm. The parallel plate arrangement is of the usual type, with four levelling screws.

description: Made by F. W. Breithaupt and Son, Cassel. 1859 This is a later modification of a level designed and constructed by F. W. Breithaupt in 1845, with the idea of minimizing the instrumental adjustments usually necessary as a preliminary to taking levels. The method of weighting the main spirit level and suspending it freely in pin bearings attached to the telescope enables the surveyor to compensate by double readings the errors arising from non-parallelism of the spirit-level axis, telescope axis, and line of sight. In this level the telescope can be rotated in its collars through a complete half-turn, the extreme positions being determined by mechanical stops. The spirit level, whilst revolving with the telescope, does not rotate, but is kept with its engraved scale uppermost. Consequently the bubble is always visible against the scale, and its variation during the rotation measures the extent to which the axis of the spirit level is inclined to the axis of rotation of the telescope. Such an inclination, if small, will be automatically rendered ineffective provided two readings of the levelling staff are made with the spirit level “centred,” one before the telescope is rotated in its collars through 180°, and the other after. This double reading also corrects for lack of coincidence between the mechanical axis of rotation of the telescope and the line of sight. The mean of the two readings will be the true reading which would be obtained if the three axes of spirit level, telescope rings and vision were mutually parallel. Thus it is not necessary to adjust the instrument beforehand for this parallelism. It is, however, essential that the spirit level itself should be so adjusted that when its bubble is central, its own axis of rotation reversing the spirit level in its bearings should be horizontal. This can be tested by centring the bubble, and reading the bubble again. Half the difference is removed by the means of the two capstan-headed screws which fix one end of the bubble tube to its case. To enable the spirit level to be so reversed, one bearing pin can be withdrawn from its supporting bracket. The lower part of the instrument is provided with a circular box level, which serves to set the main axis nearly vertical by means of the footscrews. No attempt is made to render this axis exactly vertical, as the telescope is always finally levelled by means of the elevating screw. The head of this latter is divided, and serves to measure very accurately small gradients. The diaphragm of the telescope has two horizontal subtense wires in addition to the central levelling wires, so that the instrument can be used to measure distances. The “suspension” spirit level of the type here shown was soon superseded in compensating levels by Amsler’s two-sided “reversion” level, which is much less liable to be injured by shocks than Breithaupt’s pattern.

description: The Y-s of an ordinary reversible level are replaced in this instrument by a strong and rigid socket, from which the telescope can be bodily withdrawn and replaced after reversion end for end in the “ collimation ” adjustment. Accurately turned flanges on the telescope fit in collars fixed at the ends of the socket. A stop flange at the eyepiece end of the telescope abuts against the end of the socket when the telescope is in the correct position, and can be fixed to the socket by a screw. The socket is fixed to the horizontal rotating arm by end fittings which permit it to be adjusted on this arm by elevating or depressing one end. The main spirit level is similarly attached in adjustable bearings above the socket, parallel to its axis. A small cross level is fitted at right angles to the axis above the socket at one end. Each division of the main level is 0·1 in. long, corresponding to 20 seconds of elevation. The rotating arm carries a central circular compass, of 3·5 in. diameter, graduated in half-degrees, and read by a prismatic reader. The needle can be lifted from its pivot and clamped by turning a screw at one end of the arm. The conical socket carrying the axis of rotation is fixed to the tribrach, in the arms of which engage three footscrews. The feet of these are firmly attached to a trivet stage which can be screwed to the tripod head. This stage has three pointed feet which serve to fix the instrument to a platform when the tripod is inconvenient. The telescope has an objective of 14 in. focal length and 1·55 in. clear aperture, and an inverting screw-focussing eyepiece magnifying 28 times. The objective end of the telescope is focussed by a rack and pinion arrangement actuated by a screw at one side of the eye end. The glass diaphragm has two vertical and one horizontal lines engraved upon it, whilst short horizontal lines etched parallel to the sight line can be used for stadia observations.

description: The compactness and rigidity which are the chief features of the dumpy level have been increased in instruments of recent construction by the employment of an internal focussing lens, which moves between the fixed objective and diaphragm. The telescope tube can thus be rendered more compact, dust-proof and water-tight, whilst the act of focussing is less likely to disturb the line of collimation. In the instrument exhibited, the telescope has a focal length of 9 in. and a clear aperture of 1·4 in. and is provided with a tribrach mounting, with three levelling screws. A 2-in. ring, divided every 2°, is fitted round the upper rim of the tribrach and enables the azimuth angle to be read by means of an index on the telescope socket. A tangent clamp and fine motion screw are also fitted to the tribrach. The feet of the levelling screws pass through a locking plate having a threaded central aperture to receive the clamping piece which attaches the instrument to its tripod. A sensitive tube level, the casing of which also supports a small circular box level, is mounted in adjustable bearings at one side of the telescope. The eyepiece of the telescope is inverting and screw focussing, and has a magnification of 24 diameters.
interpretation: The compactness and rigidity which are the chief features of the dumpy level have been increased in instruments of recent construction by the employment of an internal focussing lens, which moves between the fixed objective and diaphragm. The telescope tube can thus be rendered more compact, dust-proof and water-tight, whilst the act of focussing is less likely to disturb the line of collimation.

description: This is a modern dumpy level having a fixed objective of 1·5 in. aperture and a fixed glass diaphragm sealing the other end of the 10-in. telescope tube, which is thereby rendered dustproof; a movable internal concave lens is actuated by an external milled head for focussing, and a screw-focussing inverting eyepiece is provided. A 5-in. bubble tube is adjustably mounted on the left of the telescope and has a sensitivity of 20 seconds of elevation per 0·1 in. division of its scale; by means of a hinged reflecting mirror mounted above its scale, it is read by the operator without moving his other eye from the telescope. The telescope tube is permanently fixed to the inner vertical axis of the instrument and rotates within the conical socket of the tribrach levelling base, which has the usual three footscrews connecting it to the trivet stage; dustproof caps are fitted above the heads of the footscrews and their feet are firmly gripped in the grooves of the trivet stage; this latter has a central screwed aperture for attachment to the tripod head, but has also three pointed feet for mounting on a platform without the tripod. The axis clamp and tangent screw of the azimuth motion are of the usual type.

description: The optical arrangements for adjusting the collimation axis of the telescope and viewing the bubble are the same in this instrument as in the well-known Zeiss Wild level, but the elevating screw mechanism and tribrach are of the makers’ own design. In order to obviate the necessity for reversing the telescope end for end in the collimation adjustment, it is provided with two similar objectives, one fixed at each end of the tube, and an internal focussing lens. The eyepiece can be fitted at either end, and the nearer objective lens then becomes the diaphragm; each lens is graticuled for this purpose. A screw-focussing eyepiece tube is fitted at the normal eyepiece end, and the objective cap has a central sheath aperture in which the eyepiece can slide at the other end. The normal diaphragm lens has horizontal stadia lines as well as the usual cross lines; the other lens has only a simple cross. The telescope is supported in a central horizontal socket, in which it can rotate through 180° about its own axis. The bubble tube is adjustably fixed at one side of the telescope and rotates with it in the socket; it has apertures at the top and bottom for reading its bubble before and after rotation. A system of prisms mounted above the bubble tube permits the observer to view the two ends of the bubble in his normal position for observing the staff, the bubble being viewed with the left eye and the staff with the right. The socket supporting the telescope is itself mounted upon an elevating platform, which can turn in azimuth about the vertical axis of the tribrach. The telescope socket is pivoted centrally to this platform about a horizontal axis intersecting the main vertical axis of rotation, and can be rotated about this pivot by means of a micrometer elevating screw threaded in the platform at one end; the screw does not impinge on the socket, but on an intermediate lever arm pivoted horizontally at the other end of the platform and in contact with the socket near this pivot. A spring connecting the socket and platform keeps the former pressed against the lever arm. By this arrangement the weight of the telescope is taken off the elevating screw and its rotation about the central pivot is only a small part of what it would be without the lever arm.

By this arrangement the weight of the telescope is taken off the elevating screw and its rotation about the central pivot is only a small part of what it would be without the lever arm.

description: The telescope of this level has a rack-focussing objective of 1.3-in. aperture and 14-in. focal length. A 6-in. bubble-tube is mounted adjustably beneath it and has a sensitivity of 22 seconds per 0.1 in. division of its graduations.

interpretation: The telescope of this level has a rack-focussing objective of 1.3-in. aperture and 14-in. focal length. A 6-in. bubble-tube is mounted adjustably beneath it and has a sensitivity of 22 seconds per 0.1 in. division of its graduations.

description: A “precise” level, designed for work of the highest possible degree of accuracy, in addition to its greater sensitivity and power, possesses several features not found in ordinary levels. The chief characteristics are the additional facilities for finally levelling the telescope by means of a micrometer screw and a very sensitive bubble, which is read by a supplementary optical arrangement at the same time as the staff, and the protection of the bubble and all movable parts from temperature changes. In the level exhibited, which was introduced by the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey about the year 1900, the main bubble tube is sunk well inside the outer telescope tube, which is also covered by felt cloth. A system of mirrors and a supplementary telescope with its eyepiece at binocular distance from the main telescope, enable the observer to read at the same time the staff with his right eye and the ends of the bubble with his left.
makers_and_associated_people: [{'name': 'T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd.', 'role': 'Made'}, {'name': 'T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd.', 'role': 'lent'}, {'name': 'U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey', 'role': 'introduced'}]

description: Made and lent by E. R. Watts and Son, Ltd. about 1913 (Design basis) The special features of this level are the bubble-tube and an optical arrangement mounted in front of the objective lens to enable the staff to be read accurately to 0·001 ft. and by estimation to 0·0001 ft. : both these fittings are modified examples of the ones originally mounted on the Zeiss Precise Levels about 1913. The telescope has a screw-focussing inverting eyepiece and a fixed glass diaphragm, engraved with cross lines and horizontal stadia lines. The horizontal cross line is in the form of a very narrow Y, having its stem horizontal and its arms intersecting at a small angle on the vertical line; by this arrangement the division of the staff is bisected by one half and enclosed by the other half of the Y. If the telescope axis, when levelled, does not bisect a staff division, the optical axis is displaced slightly along the staff by means of the ante-objective fitting until a division is accurately bisected. The fitting consists of a plane glass slab of cylindrical shape, pivoted horizontally within a cap-sheath fixed over the objective end of the telescope; the slab can be rotated about its pivot axis by means of a radial lever fixed on the axis and having a pinion wheel at its outer end, which engages in the toothed face of a fixed arc mounted on the cap sheath. The opposite face of this arc is visible to the observer, and is graduated into 20 parts, each division representing 0·001 ft. on the staff, i.e., the optical axis is displaced vertically by this amount when the slab is pivoted through the corresponding arc; an index mark on the rotating lever serves to measure the arc to a tenth division, i.e., to 0·0001 ft. The telescope objective has an aperture of 1·8 in. and is fixed in the tube; an internal lens operated by an external milled head is provided for focussing the staff image on the diaphragm. The micrometer elevating mechanism of the telescope, the Zeiss pattern bubble-tube and the tribrach mountings, with clamp and tangent screw for slow azimuth rotation, are of the same type in this instrument as in the small Zeiss pattern level by the same makers, and are described in connection with the adjacent exhibit (Cat. No. 107). The micrometer drum of the elevating screw is graduated into 20 parts, each corresponding to an elevation of 1 : 10,000, whereby distances can be accurately estimated. This type of level is used in conjunction with an Invar Precise Levelling Staff of the type represented in an adjacent exhibit (Cat. No. 125).

The opposite face of this arc is visible to the observer, and is graduated into 20 parts, each division representing 0·001 ft. on the staff, i.e., the optical axis is displaced vertically by this amount when the slab is pivoted through the corresponding arc; an index mark on the rotating lever serves to measure the arc to a tenth division, i.e., to 0·0001 ft. No. 107). The micrometer drum of the elevating screw is graduated into 20 parts, each corresponding to an elevation of 1 : 10,000, whereby distances can be accurately estimated. This type of level is used in conjunction with an Invar Precise Levelling Staff of the type represented in an adjacent exhibit (Cat. No. 125).

description: This clinometer is not provided with sights, but has two plane edges at right angles and a movable spirit-level with a vernier at one end. The instrument is set on the face of the rod and the level rotated until the bubble is centred, when the zero mark of the vernier gives the inclination to a sixteenth of a degree. The arc over which the vernier moves is graduated in half degrees, each of the eight intervals between the vernier graduations being seven-eighths of a half degree. An instrument of this type is principally used for setting levelling-rods vertical, or for measuring the gradient of a rod used for determining distances in cadastral surveys. It can be set upon some kind of sighting rod and used for measuring gradients or for levelling. The spirit level is very sensitive, and the bubble moves about 0·5 cm. for every variation of a sixteenth of a degree in the inclination.
interpretation: An instrument of this type is principally used for setting levelling-rods vertical, or for measuring the gradient of a rod used for determining distances in cadastral surveys. It can be set upon some kind of sighting rod and used for measuring gradients or for levelling.

description: This instrument was made in the first half of the 19th century, and is used for measuring the elevation to the horizontal of any inclined plane on which it can be set. It is not provided with sights. It consists of two brass rulers, hinged at one end. The upper ruler carries a sensitive 6-in. spirit level and an index, which moves over a graduated brass arc fixed to the lower ruler. This latter is placed upon the surface to be measured and the other ruler revolved until the bubble of the level is centred, when it can be clamped by a screw on the index plate and the reading taken. The arc is graduated in degrees from 0° to 50°.
interpretation: used for measuring the elevation to the horizontal of any inclined plane on which it can be set.

description: In this instrument two brass rulers are hinged together at one end. The upper one has perpendicular sights at each end, of which has both an aperture backsight and a cross-wire foresight, and carries an index plate which moves over a graduated arc fixed to the lower ruler and can be clamped to this arc by a screw. A 3-in. spirit level is supported parallel to the upper ruler in bearings on the sights. The lower ruler has a socket for fixing the instrument to a stand. In using the instrument, the upper ruler is lowered until it rests on the lower and the instrument is levelled by the spirit level, after which the upper ruler is raised until the object whose angular elevation is required is sighted, and the reading of the arc taken. The arc has a radius of 4 in. and is graduated from 0° to 30° in degrees, read by estimation to tenths.
interpretation: In using the instrument, the upper ruler is lowered until it rests on the lower and the instrument is levelled by the spirit level, after which the upper ruler is raised until the object whose angular elevation is required is sighted, and the reading of the arc taken.

description: In a hand-level it is desirable that the object sighted and the levelling mechanism should be simultaneously visible. The combined level and clinometer designed by Capt. Abney, R.E., about the year 1870, utilizes the idea of reflecting the bubble of a spirit level into the line of sight of the sighting tube by means of a diagonal mirror fixed in one half of the latter, the other half being left free for sighting the object. This device had been previously used on a sextant. In the instrument exhibited, a graduated semicircle is rigidly fixed to the rectangular sighting tube, which has a pin-hole aperture and a diagonal mirror fixed beneath a slit in its upper face, vertically beneath the centre of the arc. Through this centre passes an axis, carrying a small transversely mounted spirit level at one extremity and a vernier arm near the other, which terminates in a large milled wheel. On rotating this wheel the spirit level is set at any angle to the line of sight, the angle being measured by the position of the vernier on the graduated arc. The cover of the spirit level has apertures above and below, the latter permitting an image of the bubble to be seen after reflection on the mirror, whilst the former is used when the clinometer is set on the surface whose gradient is required. The arc is graduated in degrees up to 60° on both sides of the vertical, and reads by vernier on the movable arm to 10 minutes. It also has a scale of gradients to 1 in 1, read by the edge of the vernier.

description: This example differs from the preceding one in minor details. The graduated arc is fixed to the spirit level and revolves with it, being read for angles up to 45° either way by means of a fiducial mark on the supporting bracket, which is fixed to the sighting tube. Scales of gradients up to 1 in 1 are also marked on the arc beyond the degree graduations and are read by the bevelled edges of the supporting bracket. The edge of the arc is milled, and gears with a small pinion wheel centred in the fixed bracket and rotated by a milled screw. This permits the spirit level and arc to be rotated more slowly and evenly than in the other form. The sighting tube has a circular section, which is not so convenient when the instrument is to be placed on the slope as the rectangular type.
interpretation: This example differs from the preceding one in minor details. The sighting tube has a circular section, which is not so convenient when the instrument is to be placed on the slope as the rectangular type.

description: This is similar to the preceding examples, but has also a 1 1/2-in. compass fixed on the upper surface of the sighting tube. The compass ring is graduated in degrees, numbered every 10° by quadrants from the N–S line.
interpretation: This is similar to the preceding examples, but has also a 1 1/2-in. compass fixed on the upper surface of the sighting tube. The compass ring is graduated in degrees, numbered every 10° by quadrants from the N–S line.

description: This is a modern Service clinometer for measuring to the nearest minute the angle of elevation of a plane surface. The angle is measured to the nearest degree by a rotating arm which traverses a fixed graduated sector attached to the base. The arm is slightly curved on its upper and lower surfaces, and carries a sliding spirit level whose position, when the bubble is central with respect to the scale graduated on the arm, gives the number of minutes in the angle. There are two flat mutually perpendicular base plates, one painted black and the other red, and the sector of degrees is graduated on both sides, one set numbered in black from o to 44 and the other in red from 50 to 89, for use with the corresponding base. The black base is used for angles below 45° and the red for those above. The radial arm has a radius of 5 in., and is pivoted at the centre of the graduated sector. The other end of the arm has a spring clutch, with a toothed face engaging in the teeth on the face of the sector and locking the arm in any desired position. The scale of minutes on the arm extends through a complete degree and occupies a length of 2 in. The arm is thus curved in a circle of radius about 9.5 ft. There are such scales of minutes on the front face and the rear face of the arm, the former numbered with the zero nearest the pivot and the latter in the reverse direction. The front scale is used with the black base and the rear scale with the red one.
