description: Instead of a graduated arc, this type of clinometer is provided with a rotatable drum, upon the face of which is a graduated spiral groove, upon which is recorded the amount of elevation of the surface tested. The bubble level is mounted within a gunmetal frame which has two surfaces accurately machined at right angles to each other. One end of the level is pivoted to the frame, and the other end is kept pressed against the base of the drum which rotates upon a threaded screw carried by the frame. As the drum rotates, an index on the scale the resulting elevation of the free end of the level above the pivoted end, and hence, when the bubble is centred, the elevation of the plane upon which the frame is set. No sights are provided with this instrument, which is designed for recording the slope of a plane surface with respect to the vertical or horizontal, according to which of the two plane surfaces of the instrument is in contact with the surface tested. The range of the drum scale is from 40 minutes below to 45° above zero, the first 5° being subdivided by dots to 1 minute; thereafter lines indicate every 5 minutes.

The bubble level is mounted within a gunmetal frame which has two surfaces accurately machined at right angles to each other. One end of the level is pivoted to the frame, and the other end is kept pressed against the base of the drum which rotates upon a threaded screw carried by the frame. As the drum rotates, an index on the scale the resulting elevation of the free end of the level above the pivoted end, and hence, when the bubble is centred, the elevation of the plane upon which the frame is set. No sights are provided with this instrument, which is designed for recording the slope of a plane surface with respect to the vertical or horizontal, according to which of the two plane surfaces of the instrument is in contact with the surface tested.

description: In this clinometer, one sight is fixed and the other is movable over a graduated scale engraved upon the vane; the position of the movable sight registers the inclination of the line of sight. The instrument consists of a hollow bubble arm mounted upon a gunmetal base, which has three studs on its lower face. The bubble arm is pivoted at one end to the base, and carries an adjusting screw at its other end for setting the bubble central. A folding sight vane is fitted to each end of the bubble arm, the shorter vane having a fixed aperture backsight and the longer one carrying the sliding foresight. The latter vane has two scales engraved upon it, one of degrees, subdivided to 20 minutes, and the other of tangents. The range of the scale is 0°-23° of elevation or depression.
interpretation: The position of the movable sight registers the inclination of the line of sight. The latter vane has two scales engraved upon it, one of degrees, subdivided to 20 minutes, and the other of tangents.

description: In large astronomical and surveying instruments, specially long and sensitive levels are generally provided for testing the horizontality of the telescope axis. The levels are usually fitted above the axis by bearing forks, but are sometimes suspended from it by curved brackets. The one exhibited is of the latter type, and was probably made in the early part of the 19th century. It has a bubble tube about 15 in. long by 1 1/4 in. diameter, and an ivory scale mounted on the casing and divided in tenth-inches. The brass casing of the bubble tube has end plates which fit loosely upon screwed vertical pins and can be clamped in any desired position by upper and lower capstan nuts threaded on the pins. The latter project from a horizontal brass tube, somewhat longer than the bubble tube and having the suspension brackets fastened to its ends. The upper portions of these brackets are curved and their ends turned over and provided with inverted V-plates which rest on the telescope axis. The scale divisions are numbered symmetrically from the centre. A small transverse spirit level is mounted on one end of the casing of the main level. The vertical pin at one end of the base tube is slightly adjustable by means of capstan nuts.
interpretation: In large astronomical and surveying instruments, specially long and sensitive levels are generally provided for testing the horizontality of the telescope axis.

description: This exhibit comprises twenty-two bubble tubes of various shapes, sizes and sensitivities, all except two being unmounted. Six are of the circular or “pill-box” type, the upper surface of the container being internally ground spherical, so that the bubble, when centred, occupies the space inside a circle engraved on the glass. Two of this type, which are not very sensitive and are only used for rough levelling, are shown mounted in brass cases, attached to the base-board. The remaining sixteen are tube levels, six of them having their glass containers bent as a whole into a circular shape, and the other ten being straight tubes, internally ground to various curvatures according to the desired sensitivity. The first six are not very sensitive, and are of the type used by carpenters, masons, etc. The other ten are used on surveying instruments, etc., and are usually mounted in brass cases, attached to the instrument by adjustable screws. On the larger levels of this type, division marks are graduated at 0·1 in. interval for reading the positions of the ends of the bubble, and the sensitivity is indicated by the angle of elevation of the level necessary to cause the bubble to move over one division. The most sensitive one exhibited has a sensitivity of 1 division per 5·5 seconds of elevation. This particular bubble tube has also a separate chamber at one end. When the bubble expands owing to increasing temperature, a portion of the air can be detached and transferred to the supplementary chamber through a small aperture in the separating wall, and the bubble thus reduced to its normal size.
interpretation: The 'pill-box' type has an upper surface of the container being internally ground spherical, so that the bubble, when centred, occupies the space inside a circle engraved on the glass. The sensitivity is indicated by the angle of elevation of the level necessary to cause the bubble to move over one division. When the bubble expands owing to increasing temperature, a portion of the air can be detached and transferred to the supplementary chamber through a small aperture in the separating wall, and the bubble thus reduced to its normal size.

description: This staff was made in the 18th century and consists of a graduated wooden rod 6 ft. long, 1 in. wide, and in. deep, over which can slide a sighting vane, which has a sharply defined diamond of dark wood inlaid upon a face of light wood, and fits closely to the face of the rod. The vane is moved by the observer signals that it is in line with the telescope, when the former takes the reading of an index mark on the bevelled edge of a small opening in the vane. This method of levelling was superseded about 1835 by the modern one, in which the observer himself reads the staff through the telescope, an improvement rendered possible by the improved telescopes used. The face of the staff is graduated both in inches, divided to tenths, and also in hundredths of a foot along its whole length save the top 3 in. Another rod of slightly smaller section can slide along the back of the first, being retained in position by a metal band which serves as a friction clamp. This second rod is not divided and merely serves as a stand for extending the graduated rod. Both are tipped with brass at their ends. A second vane, similar to the first, is supplied. Each has a circular shape, of diameter 5 in. The inlaid diamond has diagonals 5 in. and 2 in., the longer bisecting the vane horizontally. Pins and a metal spring fixed to the back of the vane keep it in position on the rod.
measurements: 6 ft. long;1 in. wide;in. deep;5 in.;5 in.;2 in.
interpretation: This method of levelling was superseded about 1835 by the modern one, in which the observer himself reads the staff through the telescope, an improvement rendered possible by the improved telescopes used. The face of the staff is graduated both in inches, divided to tenths, and also in hundredths of a foot along its whole length save the top 3 in. This second rod is not divided and merely serves as a stand for extending the graduated rod. The longer bisecting the vane horizontally.

description: This is an inextensible wooden staff 10·5 ft. long, having a rectangular section 2 in. wide by 1 in. deep, and is graduated in hundredths of a foot so as to be read through the telescope by the observer himself. The face of the staff is sunk slightly below the edges to preserve the graduations from abrasion. The graduation marks consist of black horizontal bands 0·01 ft. wide at uniform intervals of 0·01 ft. apart. The 0·1-ft. bands stretch right across the staff, the remainder occupying the left portion only, save at the 0·05-ft. points, where there is an additional black mark to the right of the corresponding white band. Large black numbers, horizontally set, mark the feet, the tenths being marked by smaller black numbers set vertically. A diamond is used instead of the number “five” on the latter graduations, and a dot is placed near the “nine” to distinguish it from the “six” when the numbers are seen inverted in the field of the telescope.
measurements: 10·5 ft. long, 2 in. wide, 1 in. deep, 0·01 ft. wide, 0·01 ft. apart
interpretation: graduated in hundredths of a foot so as to be read through the telescope by the observer himself. The face of the staff is sunk slightly below the edges to preserve the graduations from abrasion. A diamond is used instead of the number “five” on the latter graduations, and a dot is placed near the “nine” to distinguish it from the “six” when the numbers are seen inverted in the field of the telescope.

description: This exhibit illustrates the method of engraving wooden and invar rules for their levelling rods now adopted by Messrs. Watts. The portions to be painted black on the white surface of the rule are first gouged out to a sufficient depth and the black filled in nearly flush with the white surface; the black bands are thus rendered very durable. Two of the rules are portions of those used in the ordinary Sopwith type of staff, one showing the graduations cut and the strips gouged out, the other the finished rule, with the strips filled in and figured. The third rule is made of invar, for use in a precise levelling rod, and the bands of black at 0.02-ft. intervals are not so wide as in the other type of rod, where they are exactly 0.01 ft. wide. In the latter case the lower edges of the bands define the odd hundredths of a foot and the upper edges the even hundredths; in the invar rod, only the upper edges are used, the cross wire of the telescope being made to coincide with this edge in taking a reading. The graduations are not figured on the invar strip, but on the surrounding wood of the rod, as in the adjacent exhibit of a portion of the complete rod.
interpretation: This exhibit illustrates the method of engraving wooden and invar rules for their levelling rods now adopted by Messrs. Watts. The portions to be painted black on the white surface of the rule are first gouged out to a sufficient depth and the black filled in nearly flush with the white surface; the black bands are thus rendered very durable. Two of the rules are portions of those used in the ordinary Sopwith type of staff, one showing the graduations cut and the strips gouged out, the other the finished rule, with the strips filled in and figured. The third rule is made of invar, for use in a precise levelling rod, and the bands of black at 0.02-ft. intervals are not so wide as in the other type of rod, where they are exactly 0.01 ft. wide. In the latter case the lower edges of the bands define the odd hundredths of a foot and the upper edges the even hundredths; in the invar rod, only the upper edges are used, the cross wire of the telescope being made to coincide with this edge in taking a reading. The graduations are not figured on the invar strip, but on the surrounding wood of the rod, as in the adjacent exhibit of a portion of the complete rod.

object_name: PORTION OF INVAR PRECISE LEVELLING ROD
description: Made and lent by E. R. Watts & Son, Ltd. The advantages of a metal scale for levelling staves have until recently been counterbalanced by the tendency of such scales to expand when heated, and the difficulty of ascertaining their temperature in order to apply the necessary correction. The invention of “invar”—a nickel-steel alloy of negligible temperature coefficient—has now led to its employment in levelling rods used in precise surveys. The example shown is the lower portion of such a rod. The invar rule is painted white and engraved with black bands at intervals of 0.02 ft., every fifth band extending over the complete width (about 2 cm.) of the rule, and the others over half its width. The rule is then screwed into a central recess in the face of the wooden rod, which has an I section for strength and lightness, and is shod with a metal shoe terminating in a flat base plate; the bottom of the invar rule is flush with this plate. The face of the wooden rod is painted white and numbered opposite the marks corresponding to intervals of 0.1 ft. on the invar rule. The numbers are in black, and are inverted so as to be seen erect in the telescope of the level; a V is used instead of 5 and an N instead of 9. At the divisions of the rule corresponding to an integral number of feet from the base plate, large red numbers are painted on the wood, and are twice repeated in smaller sized numbers on the opposite side of the face so that the observer has always one of the red numbers in the telescope field. In estimating the position of the cross wire with respect to the graduated scale of the rod, the nearest 0.02-ft. mark is taken and the remaining interval found either by elevating or depressing the telescope by a fine-motion screw, or by moving an optical device which causes the image of the rod to be raised or lowered in the telescope field. The position of the cross wire is thus readily found to 0.001 ft. Inv.

description: This instrument is a closed cistern mercury barometer of the type common in the late 18th and early 19th centuries; it is specially adapted for portability and thus capable of employment in measuring altitudes. When it is being transported, the mercury can be forced up so as to fill the tube completely by turning an adjusting screw, which depresses the flexible leather base of the cistern. The aperture in the wooden case, used for reading the height of the mercury and the temperature, can also be closed by a rotating brass sheath. The barometer is graduated in inches, and reads by a vernier index, operated by a rack and pinion mechanism, to 0.002 in. A thermometer, provided with Centigrade and Fahrenheit scales, is placed near the top of the instrument. A suspension ring is fixed at the top, and is covered by a ferrule when the instrument is being carried. A screw cap at the bottom likewise serves to enclose the adjusting screw which operates on the cistern. The wooden case which encloses the lower part of the tube is graduated in inches, so that the instrument can serve as a rough measuring rod.
interpretation: This instrument is a closed cistern mercury barometer of the type common in the late 18th and early 19th centuries; it is specially adapted for portability and thus capable of employment in measuring altitudes. The wooden case which encloses the lower part of the tube is graduated in inches, so that the instrument can serve as a rough measuring rod.

description: This resembles the adjacent instrument, made by West, in its general character- istics of compactness and portability, but differs in the arrangement of the cistern. This is of the usual flexible base type, but has a supplementary syphon tube, connected to the cistern by a narrow neck, which can be closed by means of a cock. When the instrument is being used, the cock is opened, and the mercury allowed to attain a fixed height in the syphon tube. This is the zero of the barometer tube scale. For transporting the barometer, the mercury is withdrawn from the syphon tube and the cock closed, after which the flexible base of the cistern is de- pressed by means of the adjusting screw until the mercury completely fills the barometer tube. The barometer tube is graduated in inches, and read to 0·002 in. by a vernier attached to the movable index. A thermometer with Centigrade and Fahrenheit scales is fixed near the top. The window for reading this and the barometer can be closed by means of a rotating brass shutter, and a similar shutter at the bottom of the instrument serves to protect the cistern and syphon tube when required. Inv.
interpretation: This resembles the adjacent instrument, made by West, in its general characteristics of compactness and portability, but differs in the arrangement of the cistern. This is of the usual flexible base type, but has a supplementary syphon tube, connected to the cistern by a narrow neck, which can be closed by means of a cock. When the instrument is being used, the cock is opened, and the mercury allowed to attain a fixed height in the syphon tube. This is the zero of the barometer tube scale. For transporting the barometer, the mercury is withdrawn from the syphon tube and the cock closed, after which the flexible base of the cistern is depressed by means of the adjusting screw until the mercury completely fills the barometer tube. The barometer tube is graduated in inches, and read to 0·002 in. by a vernier attached to the movable index. A thermometer with Centigrade and Fahrenheit scales is fixed near the top. The window for reading this and the barometer can be closed by means of a rotating brass shutter, and a similar shutter at the bottom of the instrument serves to protect the cistern and syphon tube when required.

description: The Gay-Lussac syphon-tube mercury barometer, in which both the long and short tubes are closed completely at the end, but a small aperture in the side of the short tube permits the air to enter whilst preventing the mercury escaping, was essentially a portable instrument, and was, therefore, often used for measuring altitudes prior to the invention of the aneroid. The instrument exhibited is of this type, and was constructed probably about 1840. The barometer tube is enclosed in a brass case, at the ends of which are cork cushions. Scales graduated directly to 0·02 in. and read by movable verniers to 0·001 in. are engraved upon the case opposite the ends of the mercury. Each vernier has an index which can be set level with the top of the mercury column. The difference between the two readings then gives the height of the barometer. A thermometer, with Centigrade and Fahrenheit graduations, is fixed near the centre of the tube. This instrument is attached by brackets to a wooden stand, and can be set accurately vertical by means of three screws threaded in the lower bracket with their ends pressing against the case of the barometer. For mountain barometers a tripod stand was usually provided.
interpretation: The Gay-Lussac syphon-tube mercury barometer, in which both the long and short tubes are closed completely at the end, but a small aperture in the side of the short tube permits the air to enter whilst preventing the mercury escaping, was essentially a portable instrument, and was, therefore, often used for measuring altitudes prior to the invention of the aneroid.

description: This instrument was made about 1890, for the use of surveyors in measuring altitudes up to 4,000 ft. The zero mark of the altitude scale corresponds to a height of 32 in. in the mercury barometer. The altitude scale has a diam. of 3·5 in., and is graduated every 10 ft., single feet being estimated. The movable glass cover carries an index mark, which is set to the last height read, and a small lens for facilitating reading. The altitude scale is slightly raised on a step so that its inside graduated edge is flush with an aluminium plate fixed to the tip of the hand and provided with a mark. By this arrangement errors due to parallax are avoided. The instrument is compensated for temperature variations.
interpretation: ['for the use of surveyors in measuring altitudes up to 4,000 ft', 'The zero mark of the altitude scale corresponds to a height of 32 in. in the mercury barometer.', 'single feet being estimated.', 'The movable glass cover carries an index mark, which is set to the last height read, and a small lens for facilitating reading.', 'By this arrangement errors due to parallax are avoided.', 'The instrument is compensated for temperature variations.']

description: Made by J. Hicks. In aneroid barometers many attempts have been made to provide scales suitable for a very extended range of altitudes. This instrument shows the three concentric circular scale arrangement devised by Major H. S. S. Watkin, by which altitudes from zero to 10,860 ft. can be measured. The zero graduation corresponds to a height of 31 in. in the mercury barometer. Altitudes from zero to 3,440 ft. are marked at 20 ft. intervals on the outermost scale, which has a diameter of 3·6 in. The middle scale, of diam. 2·9 in., records altitudes from 3,440 ft. to 6,860 ft., whilst the innermost scale, of diam. 2·2 in., completes the range to 10,860 ft., every 20 ft. being marked on each scale. The corresponding mercury barometer scales are marked at 0·02 in. intervals from 31 in. to 20 in. To show which scale should be used, an indicator exhibits the number 1, 2 or 3, corresponding to the outer, middle and inner scales respectively. The number indicated is marked upon a plate worked by the mechanism, and is automatically altered when the barometer hand reaches the end of the scale concerned. The breaks in the circles are indicated by black bars. The revolving glass cover carries an index hand, which can be set to the last reading taken. The instrument is compensated for temperature variations.
measurements: diameter of 3·6 in.;diam. 2·9 in.;diam. 2·2 in.;31 in.;20 in.;0·02 in.

description: A new “thermometrical barometer” of the type here exhibited was invented by Wollaston and described by him before the Royal Society in 1817. The one exhibited was made before 1821. It is essentially a very sensitive “boiling-point” thermometer, whereby the temperature at which water boils may be found to within a thousandth of a degree Fahrenheit, and the altitude of the place determined accordingly. The bulb of the thermometer is spherical and has a diameter of about an inch. The tube has a length of 30 in. and a very fine bore, so that one degree Fahrenheit corresponds to a movement of the mercury in the tube of 4 in. This is measured by means of a brass scale fixed on the face of the rod which supports the tube. The scale is graduated to read 0·02° F. directly, and 0·002° F. by means of a movable vernier. The rod carries a double walled tin cylinder surrounding the bulb of the thermometer. The cylinder can be detached and partly filled with water, which is then boiled by means of a spirit lamp so that the steam surrounds the bulb of the thermometer. Along the side of the rod is attached a strip of paper on which is marked a scale of corrections to be applied to the temperature scale, owing probably to inequalities in the diameter of the bore of the tube. (See Phil. Trans., 1817, No. XIII and 1820.) Inv.

description: Although not so accurate as a standard barometer, a hypsometer for determining altitudes by means of the boiling point of water is more convenient for rapid surveys in mountainous districts. The example shown is of the “pocket” type much used by Alpine travellers. Its thermometer is graduated from 180° to 215° F. by 0·02°. The apparatus consists of a brass water container and steam jacket, in which the thermometer is suspended and which is fixed above a small spirit lamp for boiling the water. A brass case surrounds the lamp, which is further screened from wind by means of a black japanned tin box, provided with air holes covered by wire gauze. The thermometer is suspended with its bulb inside an inner tube connected to the boiler. An outer telescopic tube surrounds this and serves to support the thermometer in addition to forming a steam jacket enclosing the mercury as much as possible. The steam escapes by a hole in the top of this outer tube. In improved hypsometers it is made to retrace its path downwards and escape at the bottom of the steam jacket. With this apparatus altitudes are determined by means of specially prepared tables provided with the instrument, giving the heights above sea level corresponding to a particular temperature at which water boils, and also corrections to be made for latitude, mean temperature of the air, and decrease of gravity with increase of elevation.
materials: brass; tin; spirit; mercury; wire gauze
interpretation: a hypsometer for determining altitudes by means of the boiling point of water is more convenient for rapid surveys in mountainous districts. description: Carving about 100 A.D. Upon the tombstone of a Roman "Mensor," L. Aebutius Faustus, who lived about 100 A.D., is carved a crude representation of the "groma," or surveyor's cross, used by Roman surveyors to set out right angles. The photograph exhibited was taken from this tombstone, which is preserved in the Municipal Museum at Ivrea, North Italy. The carving is a somewhat conventionalized perspective sketch, showing the two crossed arms of the "stella," with only two "pondera" (weights) instead of the four usually suspended, one from each end of the "stella." The addition of the "ferramentum," or staff, to support the "stella" is also depicted, passing through the intersection of the two arms of the latter. In using such a groma, it would be set up so that one plummet hung over the station point, and one of the adjacent plummets lay in the direction from which the right angle was to be set off; a sight through the other adjacent plummet would then be taken from the station plummet.
interpretation: Used by Roman surveyors to set out right angles.
interpretation_source: ['Schöne, "Das Visirinstrument der römischen Feldmesser," Jahrb. d. Deutsch. Archäolog. Instituts, XVI, 1901, pp. 127–132']

collection: DRAWING OF A RESTORATION OF A SMALL GROMA
object_name: DRAWING OF A RESTORATION OF A SMALL GROMA
description: N/A (Reconstruction based on find near Eichstätt, Bavaria) Another example of the Roman groma, found near Eichstätt, Bavaria, has served as basis for Professor Schöne's reconstruction illustrated in this drawing. The groma discovered consisted of an iron "stella" mounted upon a "ferramentum," also of iron. The ends of the arms of the stella are bent and transfixed by iron bolts, which served to attach a square wooden frame—since perished—to the "stella," and to carry the plumb lines. The length of each side of the wooden framework was 35 cm., and the height of the "ferramentum," exclusive of the upper and lower axis pins, is 35·5 cm. This instrument was, therefore, a small type of groma, and was probably mounted upon a wooden tripod, as shown in the drawing, so that the "stella" was at approximately the height of a man from the ground.
interpretation: Reconstruction based on find near Eichstätt, Bavaria. Another example of the Roman groma This instrument was, therefore, a small type of groma, and was probably mounted upon a wooden tripod, as shown in the drawing, so that the "stella" was at approximately the height of a man from the ground.

description: Made in the Museum. Plate III, Fig. 1, p. 56. Made in the Museum During excavations in the Via Abbonanza at Pompeii, in 1912, under the direction of Cav. M. Della Corte, fragments of a Roman groma were discovered. These fragments were sufficiently preserved and complete to enable Dr. Della Corte to reconstruct the original instrument with a certainty not hitherto attained owing to the meagre data available. The instrument exhibited has been constructed in accordance with the measurements and drawings supplied by Dr. Della Corte. As previously reconstructed, the groma consisted of a cross, composed of two equal perpendicular arms intersecting at their centres, mounted upon a supporting staff (ferramentum), upon which the cross could revolve in azimuth: from the ends of the cross were suspended four plummets, through which sights were taken by the surveyor. This reconstruction comprises all the foregoing portions, with the additional modification that the cross is not supported directly upon the staff, but is pivoted upon the outer end of a curved bracket, which is in turn mounted rotatably upon the head of the staff. This arrangement enables the centre of the cross to be set above the mark on a boundary stone, whilst the staff is driven into the ground beside the stone; also, sights could be taken through opposite, not adjacent, plumb lines without interference from the staff. The wooden staff, which is nearly 2 metres long, terminates at its lower end in a fluted iron shoe, and is encircled at its upper extremity by a brass collar, along its upper and lower faces by curved brass strips, and terminating at the staff end in a brass collar and at the cross end in a brass pivot upon which the curved bracket is mounted. The horizontal distance between the cross and bracket pivot centres is 23.4 cm. The cross has a brass centre, and four tapered wooden arms, completely enclosed in thin iron sheeting and reinforced at their intersection by brass angle brackets. The bronze plummets are suspended through holes in the arms at distances of 45 cm. from the centre of the cross. Each plummet resembles its opposite in size and shape but differs from the neighbouring ones. The actual portions discovered included all the metal parts, with a few traces of wood fibres embedded therein. The total height of the instrument is alone considered problematical. (See M. Della Corte's article "Groma," in Monumenti Antichi, Accademia dei Lincei, Vol. XXVIII, 1922.) Inv. 1923-395. S.M. 1828.

interpretation: Reproduction of a Roman groma, an instrument used by surveyors for taking sights. The reconstruction was enabled by the discovery of sufficiently preserved fragments and the expertise of Dr. Della Corte. The description details modifications to the original design for improved functionality, allowing the instrument to be set above a mark on a boundary stone and enabling sights to be taken without interference from the staff.

description: This instrument consists of a hollow brass sphere of 2½ in. diam., with vertical great circle sighting slits cut every 45° in its surface. It is used like the ordinary sight-rule cross staff for setting off angles of any multiple of 45°, and was probably made towards the end of the 17th century. A socket fixed to the sphere serves to connect it to a stand.
date_made: towards the end of the 17th century
interpretation: This instrument is used like the ordinary sight-rule cross staff for setting off angles of any multiple of 45°.

description: Made by Dollond. late 18th or early 19th century. This instrument, which was made in the late 18th or early 19th century, has two 6-in. brass sight rules fixed accurately at right angles to each other and a central screw thread for attaching it to a stand. Backsights and foresights can be taken through either rule, every vertical arm having both a slit backsight and a wire foresight. This type of instrument is mostly used in detail chain and offset surveying, for setting the offset rod at right angles to the chain.
interpretation: This type of instrument is mostly used in detail chain and offset surveying, for setting the offset rod at right angles to the chain.

description: This instrument, made probably near the end of the 18th century, has two mirrors fixed to the base of a cylindrical brass box, with their planes at an angle of 45° to each other. One mirror is half unsilvered for direct vision, the other half and the whole of the second mirror being silvered, to reflect rays from objects at right angles to the line of vision. A circular aperture and rectangular windows are pierced in the side of the box opposite the mirrors.
date_made: near the end of the 18th century
interpretation: This instrument, made probably near the end of the 18th century, has two mirrors fixed to the base of a cylindrical brass box, with their planes at an angle of 45° to each other. One mirror is half unsilvered for direct vision, the other half and the whole of the second mirror being silvered, to reflect rays from objects at right angles to the line of vision. A circular aperture and rectangular windows are pierced in the side of the box opposite the mirrors.

description: In this instrument, made in the middle of the 19th century, two right-angled reflecting prisms are mounted one upon the other, with their reflecting faces perpendicular. In using the instrument the observer takes off the cap and screws it beneath the base to serve as a handgrip. Looking at the common face of the two prisms, he views objects on his left hand through the lower prism, and those on his right through the upper. Two objects which appear in the same vertical line will be at opposite ends of a line through the instrument, perpendicular to the direction of sight.
interpretation: In this instrument, two right-angled reflecting prisms are mounted one upon the other, with their reflecting faces perpendicular. In using the instrument the observer takes off the cap and screws it beneath the base to serve as a handgrip. Looking at the common face of the two prisms, he views objects on his left hand through the lower prism, and those on his right through the upper. Two objects which appear in the same vertical line will be at opposite ends of a line through the instrument, perpendicular to the direction of sight.

description: In this instrument, made probably towards the end of the 18th century, three pairs of mirrors are mounted successively in a rectangular brass box, whose sides are provided with the necessary windows. The three pairs of mirrors make angles of 22½°, 90° and 45° respectively with each other, and one mirror of each pair is left partly unsilvered for direct vision. The direct and reflected rays for each pair are thus inclined at 45°, 180° and 90° respectively.
date_made: towards the end of the 18th century
interpretation: In this instrument, three pairs of mirrors are mounted successively in a rectangular brass box, whose sides are provided with the necessary windows. The three pairs of mirrors make angles of 22½°, 90° and 45° respectively with each other, and one mirror of each pair is left partly unsilvered for direct vision. The direct and reflected rays for each pair are thus inclined at 45°, 180° and 90° respectively.

description: Presented by the Admiralty. By means of this instrument an observer can place himself in the direct line between two objects. It consists of two mirrors set in small parallel sighting tubes connected by a longer perpendicular tube. The planes of the mirrors are perpendicular and one mirror is partly unsilvered. The observer views the front object directly through the unsilvered portion and the rear object by double reflection at the two silvered surfaces. When the images coincide, he is in the direct line between the two objects. The sighting tubes are closed by glass windows where necessary.
interpretation: By means of this instrument an observer can place himself in the direct line between two objects. The observer views the front object directly through the unsilvered portion and the rear object by double reflection at the two silvered surfaces. When the images coincide, he is in the direct line between the two objects.

description: The application of the telescope and vertical arc to the alidade of a plane table took place about the same time as the corresponding addition to the theodolite. In this exhibit, made in the late 17th century, a vertical pillar fixed perpendicularly to the alidade carries the vertical semicircle and attached telescope, which can rotate about a horizontal axis in the top of the pillar. A vernier fixed to the pillar records the altitude angle of the line of sight. The alidade is 2 ft. 4 in. long by 1½ in. wide and has one edge bevelled. Over this edge, at the two extremities of the rule, are attached two plain sights, a slit backsight and a vertical wire foresight. A few inches in front of the backsight is the vertical pillar carrying the telescope axis. By means of its milled edge and a wormwheel, the socket of this pillar can be slightly rotated in azimuth, and carries the telescope with it. This serves to adjust the line of sight parallel to the bevelled edge of the rule. The semicircle has a diameter of 5 in. and is graduated in degrees up to 50° of elevation or depression. Its edge is milled and gears with a wormwheel attached to the pillar. The telescope rests in semicircular collars fixed to the diameter of the semi-circle, and is kept in place by hinged straps and screws. It has a rack-focussing objective lens of ¾ in. aperture and a fixed eyepiece tube containing a compound field lens and eyepiece with a fixed cross wire diaphragm between the two lenses of the eyepiece. A spirit level is mounted upon the telescope parallel to its axis. The vernier attached to the pillar is slightly adjustable by means of a slide and lever, and reads the vertical arc to 3 minutes.

description: This is an early 19th century outfit comprising plane table, tripod and brass alidade. The table, which is 17 in. by 15 in. can be rotated and levelled independently of the tripod. The alidade is nearly 2 ft. long and has a detachable combined back and foresight at each extremity, the slits and wires being vertically above the bevelled edge of the ruler. Various useful scales of length are engraved upon the alidade, and the rectangular boxwood frame forming the edge of the table is graduated on both faces in half degrees and tenth-inches. This frame is detachable and serves to clamp the paper to the table. Three centres corresponding to the half-degree graduations are marked on the table proper, by which means it can be used also as a theodolite. There is a dovetailed recess beneath the table for supporting a compass box (missing in the instrument exhibited) to orient the instrument, and a small spirit level is used to level the table. The brass piece connecting the table to the tripod has a conical axis and socket, and a spherical ball and socket joint for orienting and levelling the table independently of the tripod. The latter has a brass tripod head and circular tapering legs, 4 ft. long, jointed in the middle, and fitted with brass shoes at the extremities.

description: This is a small outfit of modern construction suitable for rough reconnaissance and engineering surveys. The table is 17 in. by 14 in. and has its under edges removable for inserting and clamping the drawing paper. The boxwood ruler is 12 in. long and has folding metal sights at each extremity. The back of the table has a brass plate, recessed to receive the knob of the bolt clamping it to the tripod. A small circular spirit level is used to level the table, the slope of the tripod legs being changed to effect this. A small trough compass with a 3-in. needle is provided for orienting the table. The bevelled edges of the alidade are divided in scales of 6 and 8 inches to the mile, to read 10 yd. on each scale. The sights consist of a slit backsight and strip foresight, each vertically above the centre line of the alidade.

interpretation: This is a small outfit of modern construction suitable for rough reconnaissance and engineering surveys.

description: A type of modern plane table outfit with telescopic alidade, suitable for topographical surveys of a comparatively high degree of precision, is here exhibited. Similar outfits have been extensively employed by the topographers of the U.S. Geological Survey. The table is 30 in. by 24 in., and is carefully made in sections to preserve its shape. Brass screw pins fitting into sockets at the corners and middle of the sides are used for fastening the drawing paper to the table, which is slightly recessed at these points to allow the heads of the pins to be flush with the upper surface of the board and thus permit the alidade to slide freely over the pins. The board is connected to the tripod by means of a Johnson quick-levelling socket, which permits it to be easily levelled and rotated in azimuth independently of the tripod. Two butterfly nuts control these movements of levelling and rotation, and, when tightened, clamp the table rigidly to the tripod. This latter has three split legs, 4 ft. long, attached by bolts to the metal tripod head and terminating in metal shoes. Any point on the sketch can be set vertically above the corresponding station point, after the instrument is levelled, by means of the wooden plumbing arm which consists of two pieces so jointed and marked at the joint that, when the upper piece is set flat on the table, with its point over the point on the sketch, and the joint clamped with its two marks coincident, the metal hook at the end of the second arm lies vertically beneath the point. The plumb-bob is suspended from this hook and the table moved until it lies over the station point. A flat 4-in. square metal plate, upon which are mounted two mutually perpendicular spirit levels and a central compass box with a 3-in. needle and ring divided in degrees, is used for levelling and orienting the table. The alidade consists of a flat brass ruler 20 in. long by 4 in. wide, having one edge bevelled and a central pillar projecting vertically from its upper face and supporting the telescope and attached vertical circle, and the fixed vernier for reading this latter. The vertical circle has a diameter of 4.5 in., and is divided on silver to half degrees, read by the vernier to single minutes. It is fixed with the telescope to the horizontal axis, which can rotate within a socket fixed to the vertical pillar. A tangent clamp and slow motion screw is fitted to this axis and connected to the vernier. The telescope is of the pattern usually fixed to 5-in. transit theodolites. It has a rack-focussing objective lens of 1.2 in. aperture and 8 in. focal length, and a rack-focussing eyepiece magnifying 20 diameters. The fixed diaphragm has two horizontal stadia wires as well as the usual cross wires.
measurements: 30 in. by 24 in.;4 ft. long;4-in. square;3-in. needle;20 in. long by 4 in. wide;4.5 in.;5-in.;1.2 in.;8 in.;20 diameters
interpretation: A type of modern plane table outfit with telescopic alidade, suitable for topographical surveys of a comparatively high degree of precision, is here exhibited. Similar outfits have been extensively employed by the topographers of the U.S. Geological Survey.
interpretation_source: U.S. Geological Survey

description: Made by Schmidt & Hansch, Berlin. The “Vielmesser” or Polymeter, invented by R. Jähns in 1873, is an early example of a plane table alidade adapted to measure the distance, altitude, and azimuth of a point simultaneously. It is mounted upon a horizontal plane table, and used in conjunction with a tacheometric staff of constant interval, set vertically at the distant station.
interpretation: The “Vielmesser” or Polymeter, invented by R. Jähns in 1873, is an early example of a plane table alidade adapted to measure the distance, altitude, and azimuth of a point simultaneously. It is mounted upon a horizontal plane table, and used in conjunction with a tacheometric staff of constant interval, set vertically at the distant station.

description: In this alidade devised by the Rev. A. J. Potter for use with a plane table, the usual folding sights are replaced by a single right-angled prism which is mounted at one end of the ruler, with its reflecting base vertical and parallel to the edge of the latter. Any distant object can be viewed directly above the prism, whilst an image of the object can be seen through the prism after refraction on each face and reflection on the base. When the two images thus seen are made to coincide, the edge of the ruler must point at the distant object, and the direction line of the latter can be plotted.

description: This consists of a square brass plate with an engraved circle graduated in degrees over which moves an index arm carrying a small compass box. It dates from the 17th century and was probably used for plotting the bearings of objects taken with a circumferentor.
interpretation: ['probably used for plotting the bearings of objects taken with a circumferentor.']

description: This instrument, made by Dollond about 1770, is typical of the surveyor's compass previous to the invention of Kater's mirror compass or Schmalkalder's prismatic compass. Here the position of the needle upon the graduated compass ring, which is fixed, cannot be read at the same time as the object is viewed through the sights. Consequently it is necessary to use a stand to support the compass, and a socket is attached to the base of the wooden case for this purpose. The fixed compass ring is graduated in degrees continuously from 0° to 360° in a counter-clockwise direction. The slit backsight and wire foresight are fixed to the compass box at the 0° and 180° respectively. When the object is sighted, the reading of the S. end of the needle upon the graduated ring gives the correct magnetic bearing. The compass ring is 4¼ in. diameter, and the sights are 6¼ in. apart. These latter can be folded down upon the face of the compass for transport, and a recess is provided in the lid of the wooden case for their reception. This lid, on being closed, depresses a pin which lifts the needle from its pivot and clamps it against the glass cover.
interpretation: This instrument, made by Dollond about 1770, is typical of the surveyor's compass previous to the invention of Kater's mirror compass or Schmalkalder's prismatic compass. Here the position of the needle upon the graduated compass ring, which is fixed, cannot be read at the same time as the object is viewed through the sights. Consequently it is necessary to use a stand to support the compass, and a socket is attached to the base of the wooden case for this purpose. The fixed compass ring is graduated in degrees continuously from 0° to 360° in a counter-clockwise direction. The slit backsight and wire foresight are fixed to the compass box at the 0° and 180° respectively. When the object is sighted, the reading of the S. end of the needle upon the graduated ring gives the correct magnetic bearing.

description: Made by Adams. about the end of the 18th century This compass, probably made about the end of the 18th century, differs only in minor details from the adjacent one made by Dollond. It has a 3½ in. compass ring graduated in degrees, mounted in a brass case to which sights can be fitted, and which has a threaded socket for attaching the instrument to a stand when taking bearings. The graduations are numbered every 10° in quadrants, with the 0° at the N. and S. points. Opposite these points are sliding sockets in the outer case. The two sights, each having a slit and a wire for use as backsight and foresight respectively, are mounted in these sockets when in use, or fitted within the lid of the compass case for transport. The sights are 3 in. long. The compass needle is provided with a lifting lever actuated by a pin which is depressed when the lid is fitted on the case, but has no clamping arrangement. Inv. 1909-140.
date_made: about the end of the 18th century
interpretation: This compass, probably made about the end of the 18th century, differs only in minor details from the adjacent one made by Dollond. It has a 3½ in. compass ring graduated in degrees, mounted in a brass case to which sights can be fitted, and which has a threaded socket for attaching the instrument to a stand when taking bearings. The graduations are numbered every 10° in quadrants, with the 0° at the N. and S. points. Opposite these points are sliding sockets in the outer case. The two sights, each having a slit and a wire for use as backsight and foresight respectively, are mounted in these sockets when in use, or fitted within the lid of the compass case for transport. The sights are 3 in. long. The compass needle is provided with a lifting lever actuated by a pin which is depressed when the lid is fitted on the case, but has no clamping arrangement.

description: The mirror attachment to the eye lens here shown was invented by Capt. Kater at the beginning of the 19th century, and enables the observer to view the graduations of the horizontal compass ring at the same time as he takes a sight. The compass ring is fixed to the rotating needle and is so graduated in half-degrees consecutively from 0° to 360° that correct bearings are read off immediately. The diameter of the compass card is 4½ in. The usual slit backsight and wire foresight are fixed to the compass box at a distance apart of 5 in. A small pin fixed in the case vertically beneath the backsight serves as fiducial mark, and its position on the graduated scale is seen through the mirror very clearly when the instrument is held about one foot away from the eye. The foresight can be folded down upon the top of the case, and the compass card and needle are thereby automatically lifted from the pivot and clamped. Inv. 1916-6. S.M.
interpretation: The mirror attachment to the eye lens here shown was invented by Capt. Kater at the beginning of the 19th century, and enables the observer to view the graduations of the horizontal compass ring at the same time as he takes a sight. The compass ring is fixed to the rotating needle and is so graduated in half-degrees consecutively from 0° to 360° that correct bearings are read off immediately. A small pin fixed in the case vertically beneath the backsight serves as fiducial mark, and its position on the graduated scale is seen through the mirror very clearly when the instrument is held about one foot away from the eye. The foresight can be folded down upon the top of the case, and the compass card and needle are thereby automatically lifted from the pivot and clamped.

description: Made by Schmalkalder. early part of the 19th century The reflecting mirror used by Captain Kater for viewing the graduated compass ring was superseded in 1812 by the application of Schmalkalder's prismatic eyepiece to the compass. By this means the observer can read the bearing and sight the object simultaneously, and can thus dispense with a stand for the instrument. For this reason the prismatic compass has come into general use for rapid reconnaissance surveys. The example exhibited was constructed by Schmalkalder in the early part of the 19th century. The compass card is 2½ in. in diameter, and is fixed to the magnetic needle. It is graduated in consecutive half-degrees from 0° to 360° in a clockwise direction, the N. end of the needle being under the 180° mark. The diagonal prism is attached to the plate which has a slit serving as backsight, and is ground convex on one perpendicular face so as to magnify the image of the graduated card seen by reflection at its inclined face, which is silvered. This backsight plate is jointed to the compass box, and can be folded down when the instrument is not in use. The foresight consists of a vertical wire fixed in a frame diametrically opposite the back-sight, and similarly jointed to the base so as to fold down when not in use. Mirrors and coloured glasses are attached to the sights for taking bearing upon the sun and other celestial objects. A lever is provided for lifting the needle from its pivot and locking the compass card when desired, and there is a steadying pin underneath the foresight for damping the oscillations of the card. Inv. 1905-155.
interpretation: The reflecting mirror used by Captain Kater for viewing the graduated compass ring was superseded in 1812 by the application of Schmalkalder's prismatic eyepiece to the compass. By this means the observer can read the bearing and sight the object simultaneously, and can thus dispense with a stand for the instrument. For this reason the prismatic compass has come into general use for rapid reconnaissance surveys.

description: This instrument, constructed in the early part of the 19th century, is essentially a combined theodolite and prismatic compass. The telescopic alidade, which carries the prismatic eyepiece and a vernier underneath this, can be rotated about the vertical axis independently of the compass box, the instrument thus acting as a theodolite—or can be rotated together with the compass ring, in which case it fulfills the functions of a prismatic compass. The compass ring is graduated directly to 20' in a clockwise direction and is read by vernier to single minutes. The instrument is attached to a stand by means of a ball and socket arrangement, and can be levelled independently of the stand by four screws which engage in threads in the socket and press against the vertical axis. There is also a tangent clamp and slow motion screw for rotating the whole instrument in azimuth, whilst a circular rack and pinion inside the compass box serves to rotate the alidade independently. This is actuated by the screw projecting beneath the compass. The telescope carries a small spirit level, and is screwed at the eyepiece end to a brass plate hinged to a sliding piece, whilst it rests at the objective end in a Y-piece fixed to another sliding piece. These two sliding pieces terminate at their lower ends in screws, which work in threaded plates screwed to the compass box. Thus the telescope can be elevated at either end with respect to the compass box and can be adjusted so as to be horizontal. It is focussed by sliding the objective lens.
interpretation: This instrument, constructed in the early part of the 19th century, is essentially a combined theodolite and prismatic compass. The telescopic alidade, which carries the prismatic eyepiece and a vernier underneath this, can be rotated about the vertical axis independently of the compass box, the instrument thus acting as a theodolite—or can be rotated together with the compass ring, in which case it fulfills the functions of a prismatic compass.

description: The quadrant attached to this instrument, which is in other respects similar to the Schmalcalder prismatic compass, enables it to be used for measuring altitudes as well as taking magnetic bearings. The quadrant has separate sights and a small spirit level fixed to a movable radial arm. A mark engraved on the outer end of this arm registers the altitude upon the graduated arc of the quadrant when the arm is horizontal and the sights are directed upon the distant object. The compass ring is 2½ in. in diam. and is fixed to the rotating magnetic needle. It is graduated continuously in half-degrees from 0° to 360°. As the N. point of the needle is attached at the 180° mark of the ring, the correct bearing of the object sighted is read off directly through the prismatic eyepiece attached to the slit back-sight. A small spirit level is fixed to the bottom of the case inside and serves to set the compass horizontal. The altitude quadrant has a radius of 2 in. and is attached to the wire foresight of the compass. It is graduated in degrees from 0° to 90°, the radius corresponding to the former being parallel to the compass plane, and carrying the supplementary sights, a pin-hole back-sight and a cross-wire foresight, for determining altitudes. Mirrors and coloured glasses are attached to the two compass sights for taking bearings on high objects such as the sun.
interpretation: The quadrant attached to this instrument, which is in other respects similar to the Schmalcalder prismatic compass, enables it to be used for measuring altitudes as well as taking magnetic bearings. The quadrant has separate sights and a small spirit level fixed to a movable radial arm. A mark engraved on the outer end of this arm registers the altitude upon the graduated arc of the quadrant when the arm is horizontal and the sights are directed upon the distant object. As the N. point of the needle is attached at the 180° mark of the ring, the correct bearing of the object sighted is read off directly through the prismatic eyepiece attached to the slit back-sight. A small spirit level is fixed to the bottom of the case inside and serves to set the compass horizontal. Mirrors and coloured glasses are attached to the two compass sights for taking bearings on high objects such as the sun.

description: In this instrument, constructed about the middle of the 19th century, the method of lifting and locking the compass card is similar to that employed by Schmalcalder. The card is graduated in degrees, in two sets numbered consecutively in the clockwise sense from 0° to 180°. There are no mirrors or coloured glasses for celestial observations.
date_made: about the middle of the 19th century
interpretation: The method of lifting and locking the compass card is similar to that employed by Schmalcalder. The card is graduated in degrees, in two sets numbered consecutively in the clockwise sense from 0° to 180°. There are no mirrors or coloured glasses for celestial observations. it can be read by estimation to the nearest 10'.

description: This instrument, which was made about the middle of the 19th century, differs very little from those made by Schmalcalder about 30 years previously. The compass card is not graduated continuously from 0° to 360°, but in two sets of 180°, both in the clockwise sense. It reads directly to half-degrees, and by estimation to 10'. The compass card is lifted and clamped by folding down the foresight. The diameter of the compass ring is 3 3/4 in. The usual mirror and coloured glasses are provided for observing celestial objects. The eye prism is adjustable for focussing, and there is a steadying pin under the foresight for damping the oscillations of the compass needle.
date_made: about the middle of the 19th century
measurements: diameter of the compass ring is 3 3/4 in
interpretation: The compass card is not graduated continuously from 0° to 360°, but in two sets of 180°, both in the clockwise sense. It reads directly to half-degrees, and by estimation to 10'. The compass card is lifted and clamped by folding down the foresight. The usual mirror and coloured glasses are provided for observing celestial objects. The eye prism is adjustable for focussing, and there is a steadying pin under the foresight for damping the oscillations of the compass needle.

description: Except for the arrangement to lift and lock the compass card, this instrument differs very little from those made by Schmalcalder nearly a century previously. The compass card, prismatic eyepiece, steadying pin, etc., remain the same, but the eyepiece is here arranged so that the eye must be nearer the slit for focussing than in Schmalcalder's instruments, whilst the folding down of the foresight upon the compass automatically lifts and clamps the card. The compass card is 5 in. in diameter, and a duplicate card is provided. The card is graduated in half-degrees in the usual clockwise sense. Both the sights can be folded down, and the prismatic eyepiece can be adjusted for focussing the gradua-tions. There are the usual mirrors and coloured glasses for taking bearings of celestial objects. A socket is rigidly fixed to the base of the compass box for attaching it to a stand. When the compass is so mounted, bearings can be taken to within 15', and estimated to the nearest 5'.
interpretation: This instrument differs very little from those made by Schmalcalder nearly a century previously. The compass card, prismatic eyepiece, steadying pin, etc., remain the same, but the eyepiece is here arranged so that the eye must be nearer the slit for focussing than in Schmalcalder's instruments, whilst the folding down of the foresight upon the compass automatically lifts and clamps the card. The card is graduated in half-degrees in the usual clockwise sense. Both the sights can be folded down, and the prismatic eyepiece can be adjusted for focussing the gradua-tions. There are the usual mirrors and coloured glasses for taking bearings of celestial objects. A socket is rigidly fixed to the base of the compass box for attaching it to a stand. When the compass is so mounted, bearings can be taken to within 15', and estimated to the nearest 5'.

description: This is a modern type of compass specially designed for rough surveying and for night marching upon a given bearing, previously set off on the edge of the compass. It has a hair foresight upon the hinged lid, and a slit backsight upon the hinged mounting carrying the prismatic reader. Various marks in luminous paint upon the lid, cover plate and dial of the compass are used in night marching. The compass has a spring damping pin for checking the oscillations of the dial as well as a lifting pin for locking it when not in use. The luminous marks on the lid are at the extremities of the hair foresight. The glass cover plate of the compass box also has a luminous mark and can be independently rotated so as to set this mark at any angle to the sight line. The angle so set is measured by means of an index mark on the cover in conjunction with the graduated edge of the compass box. This is set to the bearing upon which it is desired to march, and the cover plate locked by means of a spring catch which engages in the milled edge of the plate. The dial of the compass, which is fixed to the magnetic needle and pivoted so as to rotate freely, has a luminous arrow marked above the north pole of the magnet. When the compass is turned until the luminous mark on the cover plate lies above the luminous arrow on the dial, the luminous marks at the extremity of the hair line on the lid point in the direction it is desired to march. For surveying purposes the compass dial is graduated in degrees round its edge, the numbers being inverted so as to appear upright when seen through the prism, and so arranged that the correct bearing of the line of sight is read directly through the prism. There is a supplementary set of numbered graduations every 5° for direct reading without using the prism. A ring is hinged to the box to steady it when taking bearings, and a lever on the lid automatically actuates the lifting pin when the lid is closed.
interpretation: This is a modern type of compass specially designed for rough surveying and for night marching upon a given bearing, previously set off on the edge of the compass.

description: This instrument combines the advantages of prismatic reading with the rapid and accurate setting afforded by nearly floating the compass card in a liquid, which reduces the friction of the pivot and rapidly damps the motion of the card. The dial can be illuminated for night reading by means of an electric bulb fixed beneath the transparent base of the compass box. A socket attached to the base enables the compass to be mounted upon the tripod exhibited with it. The compass card has a diameter of 2·5 in. and is graduated in degrees, read by an internal index point mounted beneath the centre of the prismatic reader. The card carries two cylindrical magnetic needles fixed below it with their axes parallel, and has a central buoyant chamber resting upon the pivot. The card, needles and pivot are enclosed in a watertight chamber filled with a mixture of water and alcohol, which has a low freezing point. The card just rests upon the pivot, without pressing much on it, so that there is little frictional resistance to its rotation, and its motion is nearly "critically damped" by the liquid so that it takes up its new setting after rotation within a few seconds. The prismatic reader has a V-shaped backsight used with the long foresight bracket upon which is a travelling foresight. Owing to the freedom of the needle from vibration, the reading can be taken to the nearest fifth degree. The electric bulb serving to illuminate the dial for night reading is operated by a plug switch and a battery of two small cells, carried in the leather case used for transporting the compass.
interpretation: This instrument combines the advantages of prismatic reading with the rapid and accurate setting afforded by nearly floating the compass card in a liquid, which reduces the friction of the pivot and rapidly damps the motion of the card. The dial can be illuminated for night reading by means of an electric bulb fixed beneath the transparent base of the compass box. A socket attached to the base enables the compass to be mounted upon the tripod exhibited with it. The card carries two cylindrical magnetic needles fixed below it with their axes parallel, and has a central buoyant chamber resting upon the pivot. The card, needles and pivot are enclosed in a watertight chamber filled with a mixture of water and alcohol, which has a low freezing point. The card just rests upon the pivot, without pressing much on it, so that there is little frictional resistance to its rotation, and its motion is nearly "critically damped" by the liquid so that it takes up its new setting after rotation within a few seconds. The prismatic reader has a V-shaped backsight used with the long foresight bracket upon which is a travelling foresight. Owing to the freedom of the needle from vibration, the reading can be taken to the nearest fifth degree. The electric bulb serving to illuminate the dial for night reading is operated by a plug switch and a battery of two small cells, carried in the leather case used for transporting the compass.

description: In this type of military compass, invented by Capt. Burnier about 1850, the graduated edge of the compass ring, which is fixed to the needle and rotates with it, is perpendicular to the plane of the needle. The bearing of the sighting thread can therefore be viewed at the same time as a sight is taken. A weighted disc is mounted parallel to the compass ring, and has a similar graduated edge. On clamping the compass ring and bringing the planes of both rings vertical, the disc is unclamped and serves as a clinometer. Either ring is viewed through a cylindrical eye lens, which closes the brass case and is about 2 cm. distant from the graduated edges. A double-jointed socket attached to the base of the case permits the instrument to be rotated in a vertical or a horizontal plane upon a stick stand, and serves as a support for holding the instrument when no stand is used. The compass ring is graduated in degrees continuously from 0° to 360°, and the magnetic bearing of the object sighted is read off directly. The clinometer ring is likewise graduated in degrees, and is weighted at the 90° portion. Each ring is 4 cm. diameter and has an edge 2 mm. deep. The usual folding slit and wire sights are attached to the top of the case, and are easily viewed simultaneously with the graduated rings when the instrument is held about a foot from the eye. A wire mounted within the case near the graduated edges in the plane of these two sights serves as fiducial mark. The whole instrument is compact and serviceable, and is in general use on the Continent for military and reconnaissance surveys.
measurements: ['2 cm.', '4 cm. diameter', '2 mm. deep', 'about a foot']
interpretation: In this type of military compass, the graduated edge of the compass ring, which is fixed to the needle and rotates with it, is perpendicular to the plane of the needle. The bearing of the sighting thread can therefore be viewed at the same time as a sight is taken. A weighted disc is mounted parallel to the compass ring, and has a similar graduated edge. On clamping the compass ring and bringing the planes of both rings vertical, the disc is unclamped and serves as a clinometer. The whole instrument is compact and serviceable, and is in general use on the Continent for military and reconnaissance surveys.
interpretation_source: ['Laussedat\'s "Recherches sur les Instruments Topographiques," Vol. I, p. 306']

description: These two examples of Casella's " Pocket Altazimuth," or combined compass and clinometer, illustrate the experimental stages of development of the instrument, which is represented in its modern form by an adjacent exhibit. Each instrument consists of two graduated aluminium rings separately mounted upon pivots along the axis of a single cylindrical metal box, which is closed by glass faces. A magnetic needle is fixed to one ring, which acts as a compass to determine azimuths, whilst the other ring is loaded at one point and serves as a plummet clinometer for measuring altitude angles. When not in use, each ring can be lifted from its pivots and clamped by means of a lever actuated by a sliding knob. In one instrument the graduated edges of the rings are read by means of two small telescopes, one for each ring, mounted on the metal box; a thin wire is stretched across the box between the telescopes and the rings and defines the index line, or line of sight. In the other instrument, a single telescope can be fitted so as to read either ring alternately, and also to sight upon a distant object. This telescope has a single objective lens and a dual eyepiece, comprising a lens for sighting on the distant object and a prism for reading the graduations upon the upper face of the compass or clinometer ring. In both instruments the rings are graduated in degrees, and a flat footing is attached to the box so that it can be placed upon any surface of which the inclination is to be measured.
interpretation: These two examples of Casella's " Pocket Altazimuth," or combined compass and clinometer, illustrate the experimental stages of development of the instrument, which is represented in its modern form by an adjacent exhibit. A magnetic needle is fixed to one ring, which acts as a compass to determine azimuths, whilst the other ring is loaded at one point and serves as a plummet clinometer for measuring altitude angles. When not in use, each ring can be lifted from its pivots and clamped by means of a lever actuated by a sliding knob. In one instrument the graduated edges of the rings are read by means of two small telescopes, one for each ring, mounted on the metal box; a thin wire is stretched across the box between the telescopes and the rings and defines the index line, or line of sight. In the other instrument, a single telescope can be fitted so as to read either ring alternately, and also to sight upon a distant object. This telescope has a single objective lens and a dual eyepiece, comprising a lens for sighting on the distant object and a prism for reading the graduations upon the upper face of the compass or clinometer ring. In both instruments the rings are graduated in degrees, and a flat footing is attached to the box so that it can be placed upon any surface of which the inclination is to be measured.

description: This is a compact form of combined telescopic compass and clinometer of a design embodying improvements due to Sir Francis Galton, F.R.S. Either magnetic bearings or altitude angles can be measured independently, but not simultaneously, with it. It is particularly suitable for very approximate reconnaissance surveying. It consists of two graduated rings, separately pivoted within a cylindrical case, having glass-covered ends parallel to the planes of the two rings. One of the rings is graduated at the 32 points of the compass, and has a diametrical magnetic needle whose centre rests on the pivot. The other ring is loaded at one part of its circumference and is pivoted to the case on each side. It is graduated in degrees, numbered in quadrants, with the zero point opposite the centre of gravity of the load. Both rings have a diameter of $1rac{1}{4}$ in., the external diameter of the cylindrical case being $2rac{1}{2}$ in. The compass ring only moves when its plane is horizontal, the clinometer ring when its plane is vertical. Each ring is clamped when its plane is in use, and is read by the position of an index mark on the cylindrical case. The latter carries a telescope, whose axis is parallel to the ends of the cylinder and passes through the line of pivots of the ring. The telescope has its objective tube and eyepiece tube separately fixed to the case, the latter being partly without and partly within the case, and having a slide-focussing eyepiece. A hair line is stretched across the case just behind the objective lens. A base piece for supporting the instrument is attached to the case, with its plane base parallel to the axis of the telescope. There is also a central threaded hole in the base for fixing it to a tripod. A damping spring is provided for use with the compass ring. The complete instrument weighs only 8 oz.
