description: This is a 17th-century instrument for measuring angles in either a vertical or a horizontal plane. It consists of a wooden rectangular frame to which can be screwed a brass socket in either of two positions for setting the plane of the rectangle horizontal or vertical. Two adjacent sides of the rectangle have folding brass sights at their corners for setting off right angles. A movable brass index arm, provided with folding sights, is centred on one of the sighted sides of the rectangle and rotates over a brass scale mounted on the other side. This scale is graduated to read tangents, to the nearest tenth. A clamp and screw fixed to the index arm serve to clamp it in any desired position to a brass arc fixed to the rectangle. The outer sight on the arm carries a plumb-line when the rectangle is horizontal. When vertical angles are being measured, the plumb-line is detached and fixed to a screw so that it hangs parallel to the brass scale in the plane of the rectangle.
interpretation: instrument for measuring angles in either a vertical or a horizontal plane.

description: The Dip-Sector was first designed and made by Troughton for measuring the "dip of the horizon" from an elevated observing point. The example shown was made in the early part of the 19th century. The graduated sector, index arm, index mirror and horizon mirror are the same as in the sextant, but the telescope has its eyepiece at right angles to its objective, a reflecting mirror being interposed between the two. This enables the observer to measure the zenith angle between the apparent horizon lines to his left and right. By rotating the handle through a half turn, he can measure the corresponding nadir angle. The quarter of the difference between these two readings is the required dip angle between his apparent and true horizons. The index error is eliminated in this method. The sector has a radius of 7 in. and is divided on silver from 5° to 40° every 10' and read by vernier to 10". The actual angles are only half the graduation angle, as in the sextant, but the angle read is the correct one between the two sight lines. The horizon mirror, fixed to the sector, is partly silvered and partly unsilvered. The index glass, which rotates with the index arm, is wholly silvered, and has a central index. The arm carries the vernier, and can be clamped to the sector at any point, further rotation being effected by a tangent screw. The telescope can be adjusted to vary its lateral distance from the sector by a screw, and the handle can be rotated and clamped in any position parallel to the face of the sector. Inv. 1876-1207.

By rotating the handle through a half turn, he can measure the corresponding nadir angle. The quarter of the difference between these two readings is the required dip angle between his apparent and true horizons.', 'The index error is eliminated in this method.', 'The actual angles are only half the graduation angle, as in the sextant, but the angle read is the correct one between the two sight lines.']

description: Made and lent by Newton & Co. beginning of the 19th century This example is typical of the box sextant invented by William Jones at the beginning of the 19th century. In principle, it measures angles like the sextant, but its fixed and movable mirrors are enclosed in a circular brass box, which has an aperture sighting hole and opposing window cut in its circular side. The index mirror is rotated from without the box by means of a milled head and pinion gears, and the external vernier arm is fixed on the same pivot axis as this mirror and measures its rotation on a graduated arc engraved on a silver strip embedded in the upper external surface of the box. Inv. 1865-5.
interpretation: This example is typical of the box sextant. In principle, it measures angles like the sextant, but its fixed and movable mirrors are enclosed in a circular brass box, which has an aperture sighting hole and opposing window cut in its circular side. The index mirror is rotated from without the box by means of a milled head and pinion gears, and the external vernier arm is fixed on the same pivot axis as this mirror and measures its rotation on a graduated arc engraved on a silver strip embedded in the upper external surface of the box.

description: Made by Hughes & Son. This instrument is very similar to the ordinary box sextant with open sides and is used for measuring angles in any plane. One object is viewed directly through a lateral aperture and the unsilvered half of a fixed mirror, whilst the other is viewed after double reflection at the surface of a rotating mirror and the silvered half of the fixed one.
interpretation: This instrument is very similar to the ordinary box sextant with open sides and is used for measuring angles in any plane. One object is viewed directly through a lateral aperture and the unsilvered half of a fixed mirror, whilst the other is viewed after double reflection at the surface of a rotating mirror and the silvered half of the fixed one.

description: This instrument is a crude form of altazimuth theodolite, designed for approximately locating the position of aerial objects. The altitude and azimuth angles of such an object can be measured at any moment to the nearest tenth of a degree.
interpretation: This instrument is a crude form of altazimuth theodolite, designed for approximately locating the position of aerial objects. The altitude and azimuth angles of such an object can be measured at any moment.

description: This instrument, probably of fairly modern French construction, has a hollow brass cylinder of 13 cm. diam., divided into two parts independently movable about the common vertical axis, instead of the horizontal and vernier plates of an ordinary theodolite. bearings between these standards and is used for setting the axis of the cylinder vertical. The curved face of this half is pierced by two pairs of vertical sighting slits at opposite ends of perpendicular diameters, and the lower circular edge, which is in contact with the lower half cylinder, has two opposing vernier scales engraved on it. The corresponding edge of the lower half is graduated in degrees, and read by the verniers to 2'. This half, which has a single pair of vertical sighting slits pierced in its surfaces, is mounted upon a tribrach provided with the usual three footscrews, and is fitted with a clamp and tangent screw for slow motion. The upper half cylinder can be rotated with respect to the lower half by a toothed wheel and pinion mechanism, actuated by a milled screw beneath the cylinder. The telescope is mounted so as to be always in the same vertical plane as the vernier zeros of the upper half cylinder. It has a fixed objective of 1-in. aperture and 7-in. focal length, and a rack-focussing eyepiece tube with a slide-focussing inverting eyepiece. The head of the tripod used with this instrument is also exhibited and illustrates the type usual in French construction. It is of wood, with brass slots for the feet of the tribrach, and is connected to the theodolite by a central plunger screw with opposing spring, which permits the small displacement of the instrument necessary for setting it horizontal.

The curved face of this half is pierced by two pairs of vertical sighting slits at opposite ends of perpendicular diameters, and the lower circular edge, which is in contact with the lower half cylinder, has two opposing vernier scales engraved on it. description: This instrument was designed during the war, 1914-18, for surveying from the front line trenches. The periscope attachment to the objective end of the telescope enables the observer to take azimuth angles without exposing himself or the theodolite. The latter is similar to an ordinary 3-in. vernier theodolite, except that the telescope is "broken" by a diagonal mirror in the transit axis, one half of which is hollow and forms the eyepiece tube, perpendicular to the objective tube. When in use the objective tube is vertical, pointing to the zenith, and a counterpoise fixed to its lower end below the transit axis balances the weight of the periscope. The axis of rotation of the periscope mirror is perpendicular to the transit axis, and the mirror is adjusted about this axis by means of a long brass chain. This adjustment varies the vertical angle of the line of sight, but does not change its azimuth. The 3-in. horizontal circle is graduated in half-degrees and read by opposing verniers and readers to 1'. A similar vertical circle is attached to the transit axis and read by opposing verniers fixed to the standards, but is not used with the periscope attachment. The horizontal vernier plate covers the divided circle except at the verniers and carries a spirit-level parallel to the transit axis. A perpendicular spirit-level is attached to the vertical vernier bracket. A trough compass is fitted beneath the horizontal circle and rotates with it about the vertical axis. Clamps and tangent screws are fitted to the vertical and horizontal circles, and the horizontal vernier plate. The theodolite has a tribrach mounting, with three levelling screws, which rest in a trivet stage and are locked in position by a locking plate of the Everest type. A shifting centre arrangement serves to attach the trivet stage to the tripod head, but permits a relative horizontal displacement of the two when the clamping screw is loosened.
interpretation: This instrument was designed during the war, 1914-18, for surveying from the front line trenches. The periscope attachment to the objective end of the telescope enables the observer to take azimuth angles without exposing himself or the theodolite.

description: Made by O. Fennel Söhne, Cassel.; Hensoldt 1870 These represent three types of microscope for reading the circles of small theodolites. In each case, the circles are completely enclosed in metal, dust-proof cases, and the microscopes are consequently provided with mirror reflecting tubes for illuminating the graduations. The first microscope is a "Schätz" or "Estimation" Microscope, and has a single fixed line marked in its focal plane, parallel to the graduations of the circle. It is used in theodolites having 10-cm. circles, graduated every 10'. The position of the fixed microscope line between these graduations is estimated to a single minute. (See "Zeitschrift für Vermessungswesen," 1902, p. 214-216.) The second microscope, known as a "Nonien-Mikroskop," has a fixed vernier scale marked in its focal plane, and is used for theodolites having 13-cm. circles graduated to 5'. Ten divisions of the vernier scale correspond to nine of the circle, whence the position of the zero vernier line can be read to 30", or even to 15" by estimation. Alternate graduations of the vernier scale are numbered consecutively from 0 to 5, and represent minutes. (See "Zeitschrift für Instrumentenkunde," 1912, Part V.) The third microscope, designated a "Skalen-Mikroskop," is of the type devised by Hensoldt in 1870, and is used on theodolites having 13·5-cm. circles, graduated in 20'. A fixed scale in the focal plane of the microscope has ten divisions, numbered right to left, exactly covering the interval between consecutive graduations of the circle. The position of one circle graduation on this scale can be read to one-tenth of a scale division, i.e., to 12". In this and the second microscope, the reading edges of the two scales slightly overlap each other, which ensures a sharper reading. (See "Zeitschrift für Vermessungswesen," 1879, pp. 497–507.) Inv. 1914-553. 554. 555.

description: For setting up a surveying instrument on uneven ground, the tripod head is often provided with an arrangement permitting the instrument to be quickly levelled, without moving the legs of the tripod or the foot-screws, which last are only used in the final accurate levelling. Such a device is here exhibited. The trivet stage of the instrument is screwed to a central spherical section of a hollow ball, which fits sufficiently closely into a spherical socket fixed to the tripod legs to prevent any motion other than a rotation of the ball in the socket, permitting the top of the ball to be levelled irrespective of the top of the tripod socket. A circumferential clamp, provided with three thumb pieces, is threaded upon the outside of the socket, and serves to clamp the ball tightly within this when the instrument is approximately level, as shown by a small circular spirit level fixed in the top of the ball. A shank attached beneath the top plate of the ball marks its centre, and has a loop of cord attached for centring the instrument over the station point.

interpretation: For setting up a surveying instrument on uneven ground, the tripod head is often provided with an arrangement permitting the instrument to be quickly levelled, without moving the legs of the tripod or the foot-screws, which last are only used in the final accurate levelling. Such a device is here exhibited. The trivet stage of the instrument is screwed to a central spherical section of a hollow ball, which fits sufficiently closely into a spherical socket fixed to the tripod legs to prevent any motion other than a rotation of the ball in the socket, permitting the top of the ball to be levelled irrespective of the top of the tripod socket. A circumferential clamp, provided with three thumb pieces, is threaded upon the outside of the socket, and serves to clamp the ball tightly within this when the instrument is approximately level, as shown by a small circular spirit level fixed in the top of the ball. A shank attached beneath the top plate of the ball marks its centre, and has a loop of cord attached for centring the instrument over the station point.

description: This tripod head is fitted with a "shifting centre" arrangement, permitting the centre of the attached theodolite to be displaced any distance up to about 1 in. in any direction without removing the theodolite from the tripod or altering the position of this latter. The tripod head consists of five metal parts, namely a threaded plate to which the theodolite is screwed, a shoulder plate to which the tripod legs are attached, and three other parts which together form a collar, between the flanges of which the other two plates can be clamped. The outer diameter of the collar is 1½ in., whilst the theodolite base plate and tripod shoulder plate have central apertures 2 in. and 2⅛ in. diam. respectively, so that either of them can be moved between the flanges independently, and clamped in the required relative position. A small circular spirit level is embedded in the top of the tripod plate and is used to set this approximately level.

interpretation: This property is very useful in setting the theodolite accurately over the station point.

description: The main angles of the Prinicipal Triangulation of Great Britain and Ireland were mostly measured with this altazimuth theodolite, or with a very similar one now in the possession of the Royal Society. The latter was made by Ramsden in 1787 and the one here exhibited about 1790; both were in constant use between 1792 and 1862, and several sights were taken with them during the Principal Triangulation at distances exceeding 100 miles. The theodolite here exhibited has a 3-ft. horizontal circle, divided to 10' and read to 1" by three micrometer microscopes. The circle is mounted upon ten conical radii, which project from the outer conical vertical axis; this revolves upon an inner fixed axis to which the reading microscopes and levelling foot screws are fixed. A flat horizontal bar rigidly mounted across the top of the outer axis supports the telescope axis. Two 10·5-in. vertical circles, divided to 30', and read to 3" by single microscopes mounted on the telescope axis and supporting bar are made accurately horizontal by means of two spirit levels, one 24 in. and the other 21 in. long. The telescope objective has a clear aperture of 2·5 in. and a focal length of 36 in. The erecting eyepiece generally employed magnifies 54 diam., but other eyepieces were used in special cases. The telescope diaphragm has fixed cross wires and a horizontal travelling wire controlled by a micrometer screw, and could be illuminated through the horizontal axis of rotation for night readings. Clamps and tangent screws for fine adjustment are fitted to the horizontal and vertical circles. The probable error of a single observation with this instrument was about 2″ for distances up to 70 miles. The mechanism of the microscope is illustrated in the accompanying diagram.

interpretation: The main angles of the Prinicipal Triangulation of Great Britain and Ireland were mostly measured with this altazimuth theodolite, or with a very similar one now in the possession of the Royal Society. The latter was made by Ramsden in 1787 and the one here exhibited about 1790; both were in constant use between 1792 and 1862, and several sights were taken with them during the Principal Triangulation at distances exceeding 100 miles. The probable error of a single observation with this instrument was about 2″ for distances up to 70 miles.

description: DIAGRAM OF MICROMETER MICROSCOPE. (Ramsden's 3-ft. Theodolite.) Constructed in the Museum. The method of reading a graduated scale by means of a micrometer microscope having at its focal plane a movable cross wire, was first applied to theodolites by Ramsden in the construction of his 3-ft. instruments. The diagram shows the details of his later microscopes, which were added to the original two of his theodolites, and which differ very slightly from those. The microscope has a single objective lens fixed in a tube, which is mounted in the supporting bracket and can be slightly adjusted towards or from the graduated circle of the theodolite. The base of the micrometer box is screwed to the top of this tube and has a smaller one screwed into its top; the latter carries a slide-focussing eyepiece of the usual Ramsden type. The micrometer box contains two adjustable stages having their inner surfaces contiguous and their outer surfaces touching the walls of the box. The lower edge of the aperture of the upper stage has divisions notched in it at intervals of a hundredth of an inch, every fifth notch larger than the rest. The interval between the larger scale divisions is the same as that between adjacent divisions on the graduated circle when the latter interval is magnified by the microscope objective. Thus the interval between consecutive notches is 1′ of arc on the circle. The lower stage has a cross hair attached to its inner face, and can be moved as a whole across the notched scale by rotating the micrometer head; this head is threaded on to a screwed pin fixed to one end of the stage, and is pressed against the micrometer box by a counter helical spring inside the box. The pin has 100 threads per inch, so that the cross hair moves over one division of the notched scale at each revolution of the micrometer head. The periphery of the drum on this head is divided into 60 parts, and its rotation read by the position of a knife edge fixed to the box. Thus a rotation of the drum through one division of its periphery causes the cross hair to travel through 1″ of arc on the circle. The stage carrying the notched scale can be adjusted in the box by means of a screw and counter V-spring acting on its ends until the cross hair lies over a notch when the micrometer drum reads zero. Inv. 1921-556.

The diagram shows the details of his later microscopes, which were added to the original two of his theodolites, and which differ very slightly from those.

description: This instrument was made at the commencement of the Irish survey and was first used in 1828 for checking the measurement of the Lough Foyle base by triangulation. It was further employed between 1829 and 1862 in measuring the main angles of the Principal Triangulation of Great Britain and Ireland. This theodolite differs from the adjacent 3-ft. one made by Ramsden in that its telescope can transit completely between the supporting pillars, and the horizontal circle is mounted upon a repeating stage so that both circle and microscopes can be independently rotated. The horizontal circle is 2 ft. in diam., and is divided on silver to 5′ and read by five microscopes to 1″. Two vertical circles of 12-in. diam. are fixed to the telescope; they are divided to 5′ and read by single microscopes to 2″. The telescope has a fixed objective of 27-in. focal length and 2·1-in. aperture, and a rack-focussing eyepiece tube carrying the diaphragm and erecting eyepiece. The diaphragm has one fixed horizontal wires, with five equidistant vertical wires moved laterally by a micrometer screw. The repeating stage rests by means of three footscrews upon an iron triangle fixed upon the head of the wooden tripod stand. It has an upper rotating tribrach supporting the horizontal circle and upper axis of the theodolite. The five microscopes reading this circle rotate with the telescope and upper part about this axis. Clamps and tangent screws are fitted to both circles and the repeating stage, and four spirit levels are provided for adjusting the telescope and horizontal axis of rotation.

description: This instrument was ordered in 1858 for use in a projected general survey of Egypt. It has horizontal and vertical circles, each 40-cm. diam., graduated direct on silver to 5', and each read by four micrometer microscopes direct to 2", by estimation to 0".

description: The example shown was made in 1884. Theodolites of this type were used by the Ordnance Survey in the Secondary Triangulation of the United Kingdom during the latter half of the 19th century. The example shown was made in 1884, and the probable error of a single observation made with it was about one second of arc. divided on silver to 10' and read by opposing verniers and reading microscopes to 10". The arcs are fixed to the axis of rotation carrying the telescope and counterpoise, whilst the verniers are clamped to one standard. The telescope has a rack-focussing objective of 2.5-in. aperture and 20-in. focal length, a fixed star diaphragm, and a slide-focussing Ramsden eyepiece.

interpretation: Theodolites of this type were used by the Ordnance Survey in the Secondary Triangulation of the United Kingdom during the latter half of the 19th century. The probable error of a single observation made with it was about one second of arc.

description: This theodolite was constructed in 1910 for use on the Primary (First Order) Triangulation of the United Kingdom and has already been used to observe the angles of a piece of test triangulation in North-East Scotland in 1911-12, when 29 angles were observed with a mean error of 0.517" per angle. S.M. 1366, 1367 and 1368.

description: Used between 1842 and 1850 On the destruction by fire at the Tower of London of Ramsden's zenith sector, which had previously been used to determine latitudes in the Principal Triangulation of Great Britain and Ireland, this sector was designed by Sir George Airy and constructed under his direction. It was used between 1842 and 1850 for determining the latitudes of twenty-seven stations of the Principal Triangulation. The telescope is pivoted horizontally to a revolving gunmetal frame which is itself pivoted vertically in a fixed cast-iron framework. The latter is supported upon a rectangular plate which in turn rests upon a cast-iron trough; this trough was usually screwed upon heavy wooden pickets driven into the ground. Four micrometer microscopes attached to the telescope serve to read its inclination to the zenith upon two graduated arcs, mounted upon the revolving frame. Each arc extends over 45° of a circle of radius 20.5 in., and is divided to 5' and read by the microscopes to one-quarter of a second. The telescope has an objective of aperture 3.7 in. and 46 in. focal length, a micrometer diaphragm with five fixed and one movable wires, and an inverting eyepiece of magnification 70. Three sensitive spirit levels are fixed in adjustable bearings across the back of the revolving frame. In taking observations of a star's transit, the frame is quickly rotated to permit face east and face west readings of the telescope. The probable error of a single observation of latitude with this instrument was about 1".
interpretation: On the destruction by fire at the Tower of London of Ramsden's zenith sector, which had previously been used to determine latitudes in the Principal Triangulation of Great Britain and Ireland, this sector was designed by Sir George Airy and constructed under his direction. It was used between 1842 and 1850 for determining the latitudes of twenty-seven stations of the Principal Triangulation. The probable error of a single observation of latitude with this instrument was about 1".
interpretation_source: Astronomical Observations made with Airy's Zenith Sector

description: This portable sector was made at the beginning of the 19th century for use in America and was afterwards transferred to Copenhagen. The main telescope for observing stars near the zenith is pivoted horizontally near its objective end to the top of a vertical hollow brass cylinder, which carries at its lower end the fixed graduated sector over which the eyepiece of the telescope rotates. Two micrometer microscopes fixed to the telescope serve to read its inclination to the vertical upon separate scales engraved on the sector. The scales, each of which covers about 15° and is divided to 3', start at opposite ends of the sector and overlap about 5° in the centre. A third scale, continuous across the whole sector, is read by an index and serves as a check. The telescope has an objective of 2.5-in. aperture and 45-in. focal length. Its motion over the sector is controlled by a clamp and tangent screw. The base of the vertical cylinder is connected to a horizontal circle by six vertical pillars and can rotate with this circle about a vertical axis coincident with the cylinder axis. A long plummet suspended within the cylinder along its axis rests in a water vessel, inside the pillars, and serves to set the axis vertical. Its position is observed by two perpendicular microscopes fixed in the cylinder below the graduated sector. A small telescope pivoted to the cylinder is used to observe circumpolar stars for setting the sector in the meridian. The horizontal circle has a diameter of 9 in. and is divided to 10". The vertical axis revolves inside a conical socket fixed to the tribrach, which carries three verniers for reading the circle to 10". The three levelling foot screws of the tribrach rest on the top plate of a strong mahogany tripod. A small spirit level is mounted on the cylinder for rough levelling, and an adjustable counterpoise balances the telescope.
interpretation: This portable sector was made for use in America and was afterwards transferred to Copenhagen. Used for observing stars near the zenith and circumpolar stars for setting the sector in the meridian.
interpretation_source: ["Pearson's Astronomy, 1829, Vol. II, p. 546."]

description: The zenith sector represented in these two photographs was designed by Lt.-Col. A. Strange and constructed by Troughton and Simms in 1869 for use in the Great Trigonometrical Survey of India. By means of this and a somewhat improved instrument of similar design and make, many latitudes were determined in India during the period 1884-1900; from 1890, however, a more convenient zenith telescope has been mostly employed in India for determining latitudes by Talcott's method. The instrument illustrated consists of a telescope of 4-in. aperture and 48-in. focal length, mounted rigidly upon a double sector which forms part of a graduated vertical circle of 3 ft. diam. The telescope can rotate upon a horizontal axis supported by a vertical metal pillar, and the vertical rotation is measured by means of four microscopes fixed to the frame carrying the axis. The instrument can be accurately adjusted upon its base frame so that the vertical sector revolves in the meridian plane, and its zero line is adjusted to be horizontal by means of a sensitive spirit level; the zero line is perpendicular to the telescope axis of sight, which therefore points to the zenith when the former is horizontal. The sector is graduated on silver every 5'; each limb extends over 55° and is read by two microscopes, separated 20" from each other, to single seconds; a separate smaller microscope serves to read degrees and minutes on the sector graduations. The telescope has a micrometer eyepiece fitted with a diagonal reflecting prism. A setting circle, of diameter 8 in., divided to 10' and read by vernier to 10", is mounted on the telescope near its eyepiece, and is provided with a small level and also a very sensitive one, which latter permits the instrument to be used as a zenith telescope for observations by Talcott's method.

description: This photograph illustrates a 3-in. portable zenith telescope for determining latitudes by the Talcott method. The original instrument was supplied to the Survey of India in 1909, and is a typical example of the modern zenith instrument for geodetic work. The telescope, of 3-in. aperture and about 42-in. focal length, is mounted at one end of the horizontal axis by means of a centrepiece, which also carries the Talcott level frame. The latter has two chambered levels, running 0·1 in. to 2" of arc, enclosed in special sealed cases lined with thermal insulating material, and is provided with a long sensitive clamp and slow motion screw permitting an accurate adjustment in altitude. The horizontal axis has a weight relieving spring and ball race at the telescope end and a counterpoise at the other end; it is hollow to permit illumination of the telescope field by means of an oil or electric lamp. The telescope has a steel micrometer eyepiece, giving a value of about 30" to one revolution of the micrometer screw. A 7-in. setting circle, divided on silver to 30' and reading by vernier to 1', is mounted on the telescope near the eyepiece end. A 10 in. diam. horizontal circle, divided on silver to 30' and read by vernier to 1', is mounted on the tribrach base, which is provided with three levelling foot-screws. A clamp and slow motion screw controls the vertical axis motion, and two adjustable stops are provided to enable the telescope to be rapidly rotated in azimuth through 180°. A striding level is mounted above the horizontal axis of the instrument.
interpretation: portable zenith telescope for determining latitudes by the Talcott method. The original instrument was supplied to the Survey of India in 1909, and is a typical example of the modern zenith instrument for geodetic work.

description: A transit of this type was used about 1850 by F. G. Struve in his measurement of an arc of the 52nd parallel from Haverfordwest to Eastern Russia. The telescope has a 2·7 in. objective and is "broken" where it meets the hollow transit axis, a diagonal prism being here interposed to deflect the light into the eyepiece tube at one end of this axis. The diaphragm of the Ramsden eyepiece, which has a pair of movable wires actuated by a micrometer screw in addition to an adjustable reticule, is illuminated by a lamp mounted at the other end of the transit axis. A vertical circle of 11 in. diam., divided on silver to 10', is fixed to the transit axis near the eyepiece, and is read by an index on the adjacent standard. The steel pivots of the transit axis rest on high standards projecting from the levelling platform, which is supported on the wooden tripod stand by three levelling screws, having a point, line and plane contact respectively with the bearing plates. Two small bubble-levels are used to set the base horizontal by means of the foot-screws, and the transit axis is finally adjusted horizontal by a sensitive hanging level. The telescope can be lifted from its bearings on the standards and reversed end for end by means of a rotating framework mounted inside the levelling platform and carrying two extending forks which support the transit axis during the rotation.
interpretation: A transit of this type was used about 1850 by F. G. Struve in his measurement of an arc of the 52nd parallel from Haverfordwest to Eastern Russia.
interpretation_source: Plate VI, Fig. 2, p. 86

description: PHOTOGRAPH OF TRANSIT INSTRUMENT (3-in.). Lent by T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd. Transit instruments of the type here illustrated are sufficiently portable to be used for time and longitude observations in geodetic surveys. Transits very similar to the original of this photograph have been supplied to the Colonies in recent years. The telescope, of 3-in. aperture and about 30-in. focal length, has two setting circles of 6 in. diam., reading by verniers to 20", mounted near its eyepiece end, and is mounted upon a rigid horizontal axis fitted with a long clamp and slow-motion screw. The axis rests in bearings upon a massive U-shaped frame which permits the telescope to transit, and also carries a mechanism for lifting the telescope axis from its pivots and reversing it through 180° in azimuth. The supporting frame is adjustably mounted upon a base plate which can be fixed on a masonry pier. The diaphragm of the telescope is of glass and has seven lines; it is illuminated through the transit axis by means of an electric lamp at one end of the latter. A sensitive striding level is mounted above the axis. Levels, tangent and slow motion screws are fitted to both setting circles. Inv. 1921-514.
interpretation: Transit instruments of the type here illustrated are sufficiently portable to be used for time and longitude observations in geodetic surveys. Transits very similar to the original of this photograph have been supplied to the Colonies in recent years.

description: Made by A. Jobin, Paris. Plate VII, Fig. 1, p. 90. about the year 1900 This instrument, also known as a "Prismatic Astrolabe," was designed by MM. Claude and Driencourt about the year 1900, and is used for the astronomical determination of latitude, local time and azimuth. It acts on the principle of determining the exact moment at which a known star crosses a horizontal circle of constant angle, namely 60°. The instrument exhibited is the "geodetic" model of the firm, and has a telescope of aperture 40 mm. and magnification 75 diam. Latitudes can be determined with it to 0.4" and time to 0.04/sin $\lambda$ sec., where $\lambda$ is the co-latitude of the observing station. The telescope can rotate in azimuth upon one end of a horizontal plate, which carries a mercury artificial horizon at its other end and can itself rotate above the graduated horizontal circle of the instrument. This circle is divided in degrees, serving any particular star. An equilateral glass prism of sides and height 45 mm. is mounted in front of the objective lens of the telescope, with its base vertical and apex edge horizontal. When the star is nearly at an altitude of 60°, two images are seen of it in the telescope, one by light refracted through the prism and telescope, and the other by light reflected from the mercury horizon before refraction in the prism. At the precise moment that the star crosses the 60° horizontal circle, the two images meet on the same horizontal line of the telescope graticule. By a series of similar observations of the times of crossing of known stars, both latitude and local time can be ascertained from tables. (See "Handbook of the Prismatic Astrolabe," by J. Ball and H. Knox-Shaw, 1919.) Inv. 1920-131. S.M. 1939 & 1940.

description: early part of the 19th century Fig. 2, p. 90. Plate VII. In this instrument, made in the early part of the 19th century, the vertical semicircle is fixed to the alidade with its curved edge upwards, and the telescope rotates tangentially upon it. This arrangement permits nearly vertical sights to be taken and renders the instrument suitable for mine surveying. The vertical arc and telescope can easily be detached from the alidade for packing the instrument. The horizontal circle has a diameter of 4 in. and is graduated in degrees. The vertical arc has a diameter of 3 3/8 in. and is graduated in degrees on one side. On the other side is a scale of corresponding hypotenuse increments. Both circles but have no slow-motion fittings. The alidade also carries a compass box with a 2 in. ring, graduated in degrees. The telescope has a focal length of 5 in., a clear aperture of 0.5 in., and a simple inverting eyepiece with a cross-thread diaphragm. There is no focussing arrangement. A spirit level is mounted in adjustable bearings beneath the telescope. (See "Geometrical and Graphical Essays," by G. Adams, 1813, p. 231.) Inv. 1908-120.
measurements: diameter of 4 in.; diameter of 3 3/8 in.; 2 in. ring; focal length of 5 in.; clear aperture of 0.5 in.
interpretation: This arrangement permits nearly vertical sights to be taken and renders the instrument suitable for mine surveying.
interpretation_source: "Geometrical and Graphical Essays,"

description: The plain mine surveyor's dial is very similar to the old circumferentor and has been much employed in England owing to its adaptability to surveying in low galleries and suitability for traversing. The instrument exhibited is a mid-19th-century dial, with a 5-in. compass ring graduated in degrees and a vernier fixed to the movable alidade reading to 3'. The compass ring and base are mounted upon an axial socket perpendicular to their planes and can be rotated about the central axis which fits in this socket and terminates in a spherical ball. This latter is gripped by another socket and can be clamped in any desired position so that the plane of the compass faces any direction. A slit in the socket allows the compass to take up a vertical position for measuring altitude angles. When measuring azimuth angles, the plane of the compass is levelled by means of a pair of perpendicular tube spirit levels fixed to the alidade. This is attached to the compass case, and carries combined back-sights and foresights at each end. The alidade and compass case, with the internal vernier scale, can be rotated independently of the compass ring and angles measured as in a theodolite, or the case can be clamped to the compass ring and the two rotated together about the axis of the latter for taking magnetic bearings, as in the ordinary compass. In the former case, the alidade is fitted with a tangent screw for slow-motion adjustment. The sights are 6 in. high and fixed at a distance of 1 ft. apart on the alidade. Each sight has both a slit and a pin-hole backsight and a long single-wire and a cross-wire foresight. The aperture and cross-wire sights are for use in measuring altitude angles. For this purpose the compass needle is locked by operating the lifting lever, the plane of the compass is set vertical, and the lid is placed in position on the box, and a plumb-line suspended from a stud in this lid. The opposite edge of the lid is graduated in degrees up to 45° each way and has a scale of hypotenusal increments engraved on it.
measurements: ['5-in. compass ring', "reading to 3'", '6 in. high', '1 ft. apart', 'up to 45° each way']
interpretation: The plain mine surveyor's dial is very similar to the old circumferentor and has been much employed in England owing to its adaptability to surveying in low galleries and suitability for traversing. The instrument exhibited is a mid-19th-century dial The alidade and compass case, with the internal vernier scale, can be rotated independently of the compass ring and angles measured as in a theodolite, or the case can be clamped to the compass ring and the two rotated together about the axis of the latter for taking magnetic bearings, as in the ordinary compass.

description: The chief feature of this mining dial, which is a modern example of the type invented by John Hedley in 1830, is the use of a rocking circle, pivoted externally to the compass box, to carry either plain sights or a telescope. This arrangement permits a fairly steep vertical angle to be measured, the angle being read by an index revolving with the rocking circle over a graduated semicircle fixed to the compass box. The compass ring can rotate inside the box about the vertical axis, for measuring azimuth angles independently of the needle, or can be clamped to the box for taking magnetic bearings.
interpretation: The chief feature of this mining dial, which is a modern example of the type invented by John Hedley in 1830, is the use of a rocking circle, pivoted externally to the compass box, to carry either plain sights or a telescope. This arrangement permits a fairly steep vertical angle to be measured, the angle being read by an index revolving with the rocking circle over a graduated semicircle fixed to the compass box. The compass ring can rotate inside the box about the vertical axis, for measuring azimuth angles independently of the needle, or can be clamped to the box for taking magnetic bearings.

description: Theodolites with eccentrically mounted telescopes and vertical circles, which can be transited without requiring high standards projecting from the horizontal vernier plate, have been very generally employed by Continental mine surveyors owing to their suitability for work in low galleries. The example exhibited is of this type, the transit axis being mounted just above the vernier plate and carrying a telescope and vertical circle at one end, just clear of the horizontal circle.
interpretation: Theodolites with eccentrically mounted telescopes and vertical circles, which can be transited without requiring high standards projecting from the horizontal vernier plate, have been very generally employed by Continental mine surveyors owing to their suitability for work in low galleries. The example exhibited is of this type, the transit axis being mounted just above the vernier plate and carrying a telescope and vertical circle at one end, just clear of the horizontal circle.

description: The special features of a modern mining theodolite are well illustrated in this example, of which the chief characteristics are the protection of all delicate parts from the dust and dirt inseparable from mine surveying, and the provision of means for taking sights at very short ranges and at extreme vertical angles.

interpretation: The special features of a modern mining theodolite are well illustrated in this example, of which the chief characteristics are the protection of all delicate parts from the dust and dirt inseparable from mine surveying, and the provision of means for taking sights at very short ranges and at extreme vertical angles.

description: This so-called transit is essentially a combined compass and clinometer designed for filling in the minor details of a survey, more particularly in mine surveying, as the sights can be adjusted to steep slopes without displacing the compass box from the horizontal. The position of the compass needle and the bubble of the clinometer can be read at the same time as the sight is taken by means of the mirror mounted inside the hinged lid of the compass box.
makers_and_associated_people: [{'name': 'C. F. Casella & Co., Ltd.', 'role': 'maker'}, {'name': 'C. F. Casella & Co., Ltd.', 'role': 'lender'}]

The position of the compass needle and the bubble of the clinometer can be read at the same time as the sight is taken by means of the mirror mounted inside the hinged lid of the compass box.

description: The requirements of minor and routine mine surveying, particularly in collieries, can often be met by a dial of this type, which has recently been designed by the makers to replace their Rand Model Mining Theodolite (see No. 234) where particular accuracy is not a necessity. A special feature of the dial exhibited is the sighting arrangement which is claimed to afford the advantages of open sights without the focussing difficulties of the latter. The compass box, mounted upon the tripod head by means of a ball and socket levelling arrangement, is designed for loose or fixed needle reading. It has a 5-in. horizontal circle, graduated in degrees, numbered 0-360° clockwise and read by opposing verniers to 1', and a needle circle also graduated in degrees, numbered 0-360° in the anti-clockwise sense. The readings of the two circles thus correspond and may be checked by comparison. The horizontal circle is provided with a clamp and slow-motion screw, whilst the compass box as a whole can be clamped to the base. The needle is 4·25 in. long and is mounted freely upon a steel pivot; it is provided with a lifting and clamping arrangement, designed to prevent shocks. Upon the rim of the compass box is pivoted a solid arm, carrying at its outer end the vertical circle with the sighting tube fixed thereto. The circle can rotate upon a horizontal axis in the arm, to which a vernier bracket is attached for reading the circle to 6'. The circle is of 3-in. diam., and is protected by a metal guard. The sighting tube is provided with a simple optical system of unit magnification, whereby the image of the target is brought into the same plane as the reference mark, which is a point or cross wires engraved on a glass diaphragm. The line of sight is above the centre of the compass box, and the supporting arm can be adjusted to enable vertical sights to be taken.
interpretation: The requirements of minor and routine mine surveying, particularly in collieries, can often be met by a dial of this type, which has recently been designed by the makers to replace their Rand Model Mining Theodolite (see No. 234) where particular accuracy is not a necessity. The line of sight is above the centre of the compass box, and the supporting arm can be adjusted to enable vertical sights to be taken.
interpretation_source: ['The Colliery Guardian," July 27th, 1923']

description: Many mining surveys, being based upon magnetic bearings, require an accurate determination of the magnetic meridian to serve as a periodical check and to connect them with the surface survey. The ordinary magnetic needle is not sufficiently sensitive to respond to the daily changes in the magnetic meridian, and the instrument exhibited was designed by Mr. T. Lindsay Galloway to enable the meridian to be fixed with the required accuracy. The instrument consists of a tribrach levelling stage, supporting a long cylindrical case within which is suspended an arrangement consisting of a plane mirror and a pendant connected by a fibre of unspun silk. Both mirror and pendant are mounted upon stems to which the ends of the fibre are fixed, and a small bar magnet is attached across the back of the mirror. Either the pendant stem or the mirror stem, or both together, can be clamped to the case by means of adjustable stirrup clamps, and the case can be inverted upon the tribrach levelling stage so that either the pendant or the mirror is uppermost. In using the instrument the case is first set up with the mirror above and the pendant below, and the latter is then unclamped and allowed to turn freely until it comes to rest, when it is clamped up again. By this means any twist is taken out of the fibre. The case is next inverted so that the mirror is below the pendant, whereupon it oscillates between two stops. If necessary, the case is rotated in azimuth to enable the mirror to come to rest with its plane in the magnetic meridian. If now a theodolite is directed on the mirror and adjusted until it centres the reflected image of a plummet suspended below its own axis, the line of sight will be perpendicular to the meridian.
interpretation: Many mining surveys, being based upon magnetic bearings, require an accurate determination of the magnetic meridian to serve as a periodical check and to connect them with the surface survey. The ordinary magnetic needle is not sufficiently sensitive to respond to the daily changes in the magnetic meridian, and the instrument exhibited was designed by Mr. T. Lindsay Galloway to enable the meridian to be fixed with the required accuracy. This type of magnetometer is now obsolete.
interpretation_source: A Method of Determining the Magnetic Meridian

description: This is a sextant of the usual type employed in marine surveying. It has a graduated arc of 8-in. radius, divided on silver to 10' and read by vernier and magnifier to 10". The arc extends from 0° to 150°, each numbered degree being really only half a degree. The vernier moves with the index arm, which is pivoted at the centre of the arc and carries the index mirror. A long telescope is mounted in the usual up and down piece on one outer radius of the arc and faces the horizon mirror, mounted on the other outer radius. Coloured glasses are provided for astronomical sights, and a handgrip is mounted on the under side of the frame.
interpretation: used in marine surveying

description: This sextant is believed to have belonged to the German surveying ship "Moewe." It is of the usual construction and has an arc of radius 20 cm., divided to 30' and read by vernier to 1'. The index arm, carrying the index mirror at its centre and the vernier at its extremity, is provided with a clamp and tangent screw for slow motion. Coloured glasses are fitted on pivots near both mirrors. A handgrip fixed beneath the frame is used when taking vertical angles, and has a screw socket beneath it for attaching a perpendicular handgrip used for taking horizontal angles. The telescope has two erecting eyepieces, of magnification 3 and 4 diam. respectively. A plain sight tube is also provided. The telescope supporting ring can be elevated or depressed by a fine screw in the usual manner.
interpretation: ['This sextant is believed to have belonged to the German surveying ship "Moewe."', 'A handgrip fixed beneath the frame is used when taking vertical angles, and has a screw socket beneath it for attaching a perpendicular handgrip used for taking horizontal angles.']

description: This instrument, which was salved from a German warship sunk at Scapa, has a complete graduated circle instead of a sextant, and a totally reflecting right-angled prism instead of the usual horizon mirror; it is of the type first made by Pistor and Martins in 1845. The substitution of the prism for the horizon mirror enables angles up to 180° to be taken and also gives a clearer image at extreme angles, whilst the use of a complete circle and an index arm fitted with two opposing verniers, minimizes errors due to inequalities of graduation or inaccuracy in centring the index mirror and arm. The circle has a diameter of 13 cm. and is graduated to 10', corresponding to 20' of the angle measured. This angle is read by the vernier to 20". Only part of the graduations, namely, those under one vernier, are numbered and in these a gap is left where the telescope and head of the observer foul the line of sight of the index mirror. This latter has its plane inclined at about 20° to the zeros of the index arm to which it is attached. The horizon prism is mounted with its reflecting face parallel to the index mirror when the verniers are at zero. It is opposite the lower half of the telescope, which is mounted in the usual " up and down " piece, the upper half of the field being left free from direct vision. The index arm has the usual clamp and tangent screw at one extremity, and a wooden handgrip for holding the instrument is attached beneath the circle. A reading microscope is fixed to a rotating bracket for magnifying the scales, and a set of smoked glasses for varying the illumination of the telescope field is attached to a rotating pivot near the supporting ring.
measurements: ['diameter of 13 cm', "graduated to 10'", "corresponding to 20' of the angle measured", 'read by the vernier to 20"', 'about 20°']

description: The station keeper is an instrument enabling an observer to keep himself at a fixed distance from another object, e.g., an observer in a boat from his ship, by keeping constant the angle which a known length on the distant object subtends at his position. In this type of station keeper, of which three examples are exhibited, a small glass prism of very small apex angle is mounted in a holder. The observer holds this at arm's length and views the distant fixed length partly through the prism and partly directly. If the direct sight of one extremity of the known length coincides with the image of the other extremity after refraction through the prism, his distance from the object must be invariable. The actual distance will depend upon the fixed length and the apex angle of the prism.
interpretation: The station keeper is an instrument enabling an observer to keep himself at a fixed distance from another object, e.g., an observer in a boat from his ship, by keeping constant the angle which a known length on the distant object subtends at his position. In this type of station keeper, of which three examples are exhibited, a small glass prism of very small apex angle is mounted in a holder. If the direct sight of one extremity of the known length coincides with the image of the other extremity after refraction through the prism, his distance from the object must be invariable. The actual distance will depend upon the fixed length and the apex angle of the prism.

description: This type of station keeper is essentially similar in construction to a box sextant, having a graduated arc of 6-in. radius extending over 20°. By measuring on this arc the angle subtended at his position by a fixed length on the distant object, the observer can calculate his distance from that object, or, having calculated the necessary angle, can set it on the instrument and keep his distance constant. The instrument consists of a sector-shaped box having its wider end open and its narrower end closed, save for a pin-hole aperture for sighting. At the open end, within the box, is mounted a fixed "horizon" mirror, whilst a movable index mirror is pivoted near the closed end and geared to an external rotating index arm, which moves over a graduated arc on the upper face of the box. The gearing is done by rack and pinion gear, which causes the index arm to rotate through twice the angle through which the index mirror moves. The arc is graduated in half-degrees from 0° to 20° and the index arm carries a vernier reading to 5′. In using the instrument the observer sights one end of the distant base directly through the space below the horizon mirror, and the other end by double reflection at the two mirrors, and moves his position or the index arm until the two ends appear coincident.
interpretation: This type of station keeper is essentially similar in construction to a box sextant, having a graduated arc of 6-in. radius extending over 20°. By measuring on this arc the angle subtended at his position by a fixed length on the distant object, the observer can calculate his distance from that object, or, having calculated the necessary angle, can set it on the instrument and keep his distance constant. The instrument consists of a sector-shaped box having its wider end open and its narrower end closed, save for a pin-hole aperture for sighting. At the open end, within the box, is mounted a fixed "horizon" mirror, whilst a movable index mirror is pivoted near the closed end and geared to an external rotating index arm, which moves over a graduated arc on the upper face of the box. description: The arms of a station pointer are often fitted with sights which permit the instrument to act as a theodolite and thus to measure the angles subtended by three known points at the observing station. On detaching the arm piece from the circle and applying it to the chart like an ordinary station pointer, the position of the observing station can be plotted. The instrument exhibited is of this combination type, and was salved from a German warship sunk at Scapa Flow. It has a graduated circle of 11-in. diam., with its edge divided on German silver to single degrees. This circular plate can rotate within a hollow central axis which terminates below in a spherical ball; this ball forms part of a ball and socket joint connecting the instrument to a stand. The plate can thus be set in any plane and clamped by means of a threaded collar acting on the joint; it can then be rotated in this plane and clamped by a radial screw threaded in its outer axis and impinging on its inner one. The arms of the instrument are mounted on a separate circular ring which has a central pin fitting within a hole in the centre of the plate. Each arm is pivoted round this pin and can be turned about it and clamped to the edge of the circular ring when the arm is directed towards the corresponding fixed point. The central pin acts as backsight for the observation, whilst each arm has a folding slit foresight fixed at its outer end. The subtended angles can then be read off on the graduated circle if required and the arm piece removed and applied to the chart. The bevelled edges of the arms are then made to pass through the corresponding fixed points on the chart, when the central pin marks the position of the observing station. This pin is mounted loosely in the arm piece and its point kept slightly above the plane of the arms by a spring. On depressing the head of the pin, its point makes an indentation in the chart and thus plots the position of the observing station. The arms are 14 in. long from central pin to sights, but can be extended to 20 in. by means of the three extension pieces shown. Two of the bevelled edges can be brought to coincide, but the third cannot be set less than 14° from the other two.
interpretation: The arms of a station pointer are often fitted with sights which permit the instrument to act as a theodolite and thus to measure the angles subtended by three known points at the observing station. On detaching the arm piece from the circle and applying it to the chart like an ordinary station pointer, the position of the observing station can be plotted. The instrument exhibited is of this combination type, and was salved from a German warship sunk at Scapa Flow.

description: This modified form of sextant was designed by T. Nordenfelt about 1884 for rangefinding at sea. Observations are taken with the plane of the sextant vertical from a point on board ship at a known height above sea level upon the water line of a distant object and simultaneously upon the horizon. When the horizon and water line images are made to coincide by revolving the index arm, the reading of the index on the graduated arc gives the range of the distant object directly. The index mirror is not mounted upon the pivot of the rotating arm, but upon an eccentric pivot, connected to the arm by a cam and pin mechanism, which causes the mirror to rotate through a much smaller angle than the arm; this enables the angle swept out by the reflected ray to be varied very gradually between narrow limits, whilst the index traverses an arc of 60° or thereabouts. As the angle of depression of the distant object below the horizon varies inversely as the range, if the base—i.e. the height of the observer above sea level—is constant, the arc of the sextant can be graduated to read the range directly. Different arcs are, however, necessary for different observing heights, and three are provided, two for heights of 96 ft. and the third for a height of 47 ft. ; any arc can be fixed in the sextant frame by means of clamping pins. The effect of the dip of the horizon is allowed for on the graduated arcs. The rotating arm is provided with one fixed index mark and another index which can be displaced relative to the fixed one by means of a tangent screw; the arm has a separate clamp and tangent screw. Two telescopes, of different fields and magnifications, are provided.

description: This instrument was designed for photographic surveying by Prof. E. J. Mills, F.R.S., about the year 1897. It consists of an accurately adjustable camera of nearly constant focus, fixed to the vernier plate of a 6 in. theodolite which gives the azimuth angle of the optical axis of the camera to 30", and is provided with an ordinary parallel plate four levelling screw mounting for attachment to the tripod. The photographic plates are 5 in. by 4 in. The camera box, which is made of teak, has a pair of perpendicular spirit levels and a 2-in. compass box attached to its top. The front consists of a brass plate mounted in horizontal and vertical slides, and adjusted in both directions by means of fine screws. It carries a centrally mounted Zeiss extreme angle (about 130°) anastigmat lens of 141-mm. focal length. The vertical and horizontal position of the lens is measurable by scales and verniers to 0.04 mm. The back of the camera can slide in the box and is moved by a twin rack and pinion arrangement, actuated by thumb wheels at each side. The focal length of the camera for any position of the back is read by a scale and vernier to 0.04 mm. The ground glass is graduated in centimetre squares, the central vertical and horizontal lines having millimetre graduations. Four triangular brass teeth are fixed in the centres of the edges of the back, and press against the front face of the plate during exposure. Their images on the plate after exposure serve to determine the horizon line and principal vertical line of the picture. The slides, twelve in number, are "single," and must be changed after each exposure. The base of the camera box has guides and screw threads for fixing it to the vernier plate of the theodolite, so that the principal point of the lens is vertically above the centre of the horizontal circle. This latter is graduated in half-degrees and read by opposing verniers to 30". Clamps and tangent screws for fine motion are fitted to both vernier plate and horizontal circle. The instrument is levelled by means of the spirit level on top of the camera box, and the four footscrews.
measurements: 6 in.;5 in. by 4 in.;2-in.;141-mm.;0.04 mm.;0.04 mm.;centimetre squares;millimetre graduations;half-degrees;30"
interpretation: This instrument was designed for photographic surveying.

description: In this photo-theodolite, which is of the type designed by V. Pollack for engineering surveys in mountainous districts of Austria, the camera is centrally mounted above the horizontal circle and carries the telescope and vertical circle on one side, these being counterbalanced by a weight carried on the other side. To reduce the weight, the camera box, telescope tube and support for the latter are made of aluminium. The camera objective is a Zeiss anastigmat lens f/18 of focal length 21.2 cm., mounted in a movable plate which can be elevated or depressed to the extent of 5 cm. by means of a rack and pinion arrangement; the amount of elevation or depression is measured by a vernier and scale at the side of the plate. At the back of the camera box is a rectangular brass frame, 21 cm. by 15 cm., the inner edges of which are notched every centimetre. The photographic plate is pressed against this frame and the graduations are photographed round its edges; these serve to locate the principal and horizon lines on the picture and to discover any subsequent distortion due to development. The ground glass screen which normally fits in the back of the camera has a telescopic eyepiece mounted at its centre; this eyepiece, which is pivoted on a horizontal axis, forms a central telescope with the camera lens as objective.
interpretation: In this photo-theodolite, which is of the type designed by V. description: Two views are here shown of a photo-theodolite designed by Dr. C. Pulfrich specially for use in stereo-photographic surveys. Above the camera is mounted a telescope which can sweep out a field of view perpendicular to the camera axis, so that, when the other station point of the base is sighted, the optical axis of the camera must be perpendicular to the base.
interpretation: Designed specially for use in stereo-photographic surveys.

description: The stereo-comparator is a special type of stereoscope, designed by Dr. C. Pulfrich about 1901, for measuring the relative displacement of corresponding points in the two views of an area surveyed from each end of a base, and deducing therefrom the position of the corresponding ground point with respect to the base. The position of each ground point is separately measured in terms of its azimuth, altitude and range (perpendicular to the base) from the left-hand base terminal point. The two negatives can be traversed together in a lateral direction parallel to their horizon lines by means of a rack operated by the wheel shown on the left of the instrument and known as the "direction" wheel, or the right-hand plate can be moved alone in the same direction by means of the wheel on the right-hand side of the instrument. The latter is known as the "parallax" or "distance" wheel. Each movement is registered by scales and verniers, whilst the "distance" wheel has a micrometer drum head for recording the smaller movements. The telescope can also be moved across the negative carriage in a direction parallel to the principal vertical lines of the views by means of the "height" wheel, shown in front of the middle part of the instrument, and the amount of motion measured on the "height" scale. The instrument is originally adjusted so that the mark appears to be at an infinite distance from the observer, in a direction coinciding with that of the principal point of the negatives, i.e. perpendicular to the base of the survey. When the mark is made to coincide with any point of the landscape, the readings of the direction, distance and height scales give the azimuth, range and altitude of that point with respect to the left base point. All the scales read to 0·01 mm. The instrument is designed to take negatives of dimensions 12 cm. by 9 cm., such as are used in the photo-theodolite, by Zeiss, illustrated in an adjacent photograph.

description: Early in 1907, Lieut. F. V. Thompson, R.E., at the School of Military Engineering designed the instrument illustrated in these two photographs for the purpose of automatically plotting the positions of points obtained by a stereo-photographic survey. The apparatus consists of a Pulfrich stereo-comparator, with a pair of plotting boards traversed by rulers connected to its measuring mechanism in such a manner that the co-ordinates of the point viewed in the comparator can be automatically plotted on the boards. In the Pulfrich comparator the three co-ordinates of any point surveyed, namely its direction, altitude and range, are measured by the motions of the main slide, the microscope bridge slide and the parallax slide respectively. The two plotting boards of the stereo-plotter, which may be called the plan and ele- vation boards respectively, are provided with one common "ordinate" ruler and separate "abscissa" rulers. The two latter are geared respectively to the main slide and microscope slide mechanism of the comparator, and are moved automatic- ally over their boards by the operation of setting the comparator on the view point. The ordinate ruler has to be set by hand at a distance from the plan equal to the "range" of the view point as recorded on the range drum of the comparator, which drum is operated by the mechanism of setting the parallax slide. After this setting of the ordinate ruler, its point of intersection with the abscissa ruler of the plan board gives the plan point of the view point, whilst its intersection with the abscissa ruler of the elevation board gives a reading upon a scale fixed to the ordinate ruler which registers the elevation of the view point above the camera station.
makers_and_associated_people: [{'name': 'W. Watson & Sons, Ltd.', 'role': 'presented by'}, {'name': 'F. V. Thompson', 'role': 'designed'}, {'name': 'F. V. Thompson', 'role': 'R.E.'}]
interpretation: instrument for the purpose of automatically plotting the positions of points obtained by a stereo-photographic survey.
interpretation_source: Geographical Journal

description: Photograph of the 1911 model of the Zeiss-Von Orel Stereo-Autograph. In 1908, Lieut. E. von Orel designed the first model. In 1909, Messrs. Zeiss, in conjunction with von Orel, constructed a new model. The 1911 instrument performs all functions of the 1909 model and permits the trace of any line upon the photographs to be plotted directly upon the plan. It can automatically plot contours, lines of rivers, roads, fences, etc. It also allows the optical axis of the camera used in obtaining the two stereo- photographs to be plotted.
interpretation: The stereo-autograph is a device designed for plotting points from a stereo-photographic survey. The 1911 model is an evolution of earlier models, offering automated plotting of contours and lines directly from photographs, which significantly streamlines the surveying process.
